The teaching now turns to the heart of practice—the times and signs of empowerment. This is not arbitrary scheduling. The nature itself provides the openings. The student must recognize them. A voiceWhen you receive empowerment, you are not given something new. You are shown what you already possess. The empowerment is recognition—not transformation. The seed was always present. The rain makes it visible. The tradition explains: The Tibetan distinguishes elaboration. The first teaching is about empowerment WITH elaboration. This means the elaborate ritual—the full tantric ceremony with its mandalas, its offerings, its precise timings. This is the path for those who need form to enter the formless. Why elaborate? Some minds need the scaffold. The rituals, the visualizations, the exact procedures—these are training wheels. They create the container. Then the student can rest inside. The first division covers the timing. The best years are the dragon, snake, horse, and pig years—especially the fourth year of the cycle. The best months are the first four months of the year. The results manifest when the fruit ripens. The best dates are during the waxing moon, from the first to the full. The best times are midday and midnight—these are the pivot points, the doorways between states.
[7099-8111]
Now we add final reflections on the empowerment—the synthesis of all we have taught. A voiceThe empowerment is the door to the treasury. Through it, we enter the path of Dzogchen. It is not the end—it is the beginning. But it is an essential beginning without which the path cannot be entered. The tradition explains: Without empowerment, we practice other methods—helpful, valuable, but not Dzogchen. With empowerment, we practice Dzogchen—the direct path. This is the key difference. This is why finding a qualified guru and receiving proper empowerment is essential. A bridging voice adds: The empowerment is also the confirmation of our potential. The guru sees Buddha-nature in the student and Your voice echoes through the slopes of Gangri Tokar, Chimphu, and Namtso—the echo is not your voice. it. The student recognizes what was always there. This is the transmission—mind to mind, heart to heart. Now we conclude this comprehensive teaching. A voice concludes: The times and signs of empowerment have been explained in detail—the elaborate, the non-elaborate, and the supreme. The student who understands these teachings is ready for the path. The treasury of the Supreme Vehicle—the Great Perfection—has been opened. The path is clear. The result is certain. Recognition is possible now, in this very moment. The tradition ends: Three words. See what is. The nature is present. The recognition is immediate. The liberation is now. This is Dzogchen. This is the Great Perfection. This is what you are. Emaho! May all beings recognize the nature. May all beings rest in rigpa. May all beings be liberated. May the treasury of the Supreme Vehicle shine forever. Sarva Mangalam. A voiceHow do you know when empowerment is complete? There are definite signs. The outer signs: the student's body is transformed—radiant, healthy, youthful. The channels are clear. The breath is peaceful. The voice is melodious. These are outer completion signs. The inner signs: the student's mind is transformed—clear, peaceful, wise. The three poisons diminish. The six paramitas arise naturally. The bodhicitta is stable. These are inner completion signs. The secret signs: the student recognizes the nature directly—no more doubt. The student rests in rigpa—no more grasping. The student manifests the three bodies—naturally, without effort. This is secret completion. These signs may not come all at once. They develop over time. First outer signs, then inner, then secret. But they will come if practice continues.
[7121-7140]
A voice continues: But timing alone is not enough. The student must have the qualities. The student must hold samaya—these are the commitments that protect the empowerment. The student's element-body must accord with the practice. This is not rigid—the numbers can vary from fifty to a hundred, depending on capacity. The key is accordance, not rigid formula. If the student enters the ritual without proper preparation, problems arise. If the lamp has no oil—the student has no faith—then the samaya cannot be repaired. Without purity, no Siddhi arises. If the student dies meaninglessly, obstacles arise. But if the empowerment is complete and the mantra is strong, then success comes. The tradition points: When the friends gather, observe. If the student's body experiences illness, this is a sign—the channels are clearing. Then practice circumambulation and prostration. If the student's speech becomes chaotic—this is the speech of the deity arising. Recite the hundred letters. If the mind becomes hungry or mindfulness lapses—this is the dissolution of ordinary mind into wisdom. Enter the stages of generation and completion.
[7141-7160]
A sharp voice cuts: The signs are not good or bad—they are indicators. If pure signs arise, continue the original empowerment ritual with effort. If the substances of accomplishment increase, supreme Siddhi will be obtained. The equal meaning—surrender to the teacher—is faith. When you enter empowerment with such faith, you always see good signs. Common Siddhis are accomplished through this. Even if you have some experience and knowledge, use them for the happiness of the dharma. A bridging voice adds: The guru is supreme. Faith arises in the fortunate. Through this, you apply the supreme mudra—you see your own body, speech, and mind as bliss. This is the pure Buddha field. This is the first teaching—the times and signs of elaborate empowerment.
[7161-7180]
Now the teaching turns to empowerment WITHOUT elaboration. A voiceThe second teaching is simpler. Now we describe the times and signs of non-elaborate empowerment. There is no year distinction—any year will do. Any who have knowledge can receive it. The timing is simpler: summer and winter are both good. The dates are during the waxing moon, specifically the full fortnight. The empowerment time is dawn, when the sound becomes clear. The tradition explains: The student must have faith—at least five, six, or seven qualities. More than seven is unnecessary. The student must have faith, virtue in action, praise of the guru in speech. If the body does not experience bliss, then confess past sins. For speech and mind, confess and begin fresh. This is empowerment without elaboration—its times and signs.
[7181-7200]
Now the teaching turns to the third—extreme non-elaborate empowerment, the supreme secret. A voice states: The third teaching is about supreme secret empowerment—the times and signs. There is no year distinction. It accomplishes through self-nature. This is the highest path: the outer time is when to plant the seed of awakening. The inner time is when the seed ripens. The secret time is the time of empowerment itself. When you give empowerment at the outer time, you plant the seed. When the seed sprouts and grows, the fruit accumulates. This is empowerment without elaboration—the wisdom fruit completes. The three bodies are definitely attained. The inner time is when the moon waxes—the student's experience stabilizes. Avoid the waning moon. Increase experience and blessings. The secret time is when the sun reaches its peak—the self-arising wisdom dawns. Or at the waning end—the conceptual mind exhausts itself.
[7201-7220]
A voice continues: The suitable student is one, two, or three—more is unnecessary. Each student has their own direction and time. The body time is like space—the clouds, mist, rain, wind, sounds arise and pass. If these cause harm, enemies, thieves, or unpleasant forms arise, these are signs of the student's past negative karma. After empowerment, if the guru does not show instruction, problems arise. The tradition adds: If bliss disappears or images arise, the student should circumambulate the guru's chamber a hundred thousand times—or at least six thousand. Prostrate a hundred thousand times—or at least one thousand. At that time, distinguish the signs. If the beginning is pure, the end will be pure. If the body is complete, don't cut the practice—continue. When the activity finishes, begin again. If you don't purify the sins, then meditate on the deity's thousand bodies. Then learn the sequence from the guru.
[7221-7240]
The teaching now covers speech practice. A voice explains: The student should also practice speech. The yogi should know: if beginning, middle, and end arise without interval, then recite the hundred, thousand, or hundred thousand letters with effort. If the end arises, you have succeeded. Read the tantras of secret mantra. Recite the mantras. Keep the commitments to the deity. Recite various praises. Recite the ali kali sounds. Recite the individual kyaṃ. Recite hūṃ, phaṭ, oṃ. Combine and recite various mantras for seven months with effort. The tradition states: Then receive instruction in the place of practice. Absorb the commitment deity. Meditate for three days. If signs arise in the middle, rays of mantra light radiate and gather. Continue effort for seven days. If the end arises—the letters radiate and gather—meditate. Make effort for ten days. If beginning, middle, and end all arise, you have accomplished the practice.
[7241-7260]
Now we teach the signs of accomplishment. A voice says: There are outer, inner, and secret signs. The outer signs: the body becomes like the sun and moon—radiant. The inner signs: the channels become clear like nets—the bindus flow freely. The secret signs: the mind attains the nature of great bliss—unchanging. The body signs include: the body becomes youthful, healthy, beautiful. The channels are clear. The breath is peaceful. The voice becomes like thunder or a kalavinka bird. These are outer signs. The inner signs: you see all phenomena as the deity's display. You hear the sound of the dharma. You experience the taste of wisdom. You smell the scent of purity. These are the inner signs. The secret signs: the mind rests in its own nature—empty, luminous, knowing. No conceptual thought arises. The three bodies are recognized as your own display. This is the supreme sign.
[7261-7280]
Now we teach what happens if signs do not arise. A sharp voice cuts: If outer signs do not arise, it means the channels are blocked. If inner signs do not arise, it means the mind is not trained. If secret signs do not arise, it means the recognition is not stable. The remedy: For blocked channels, practice the preliminary exercises—prostrations, mandala offerings, guru yoga. For untrained mind, practice single-pointed meditation on the deity. For unstable recognition, practice the generation and completion stages together. A bridging voice adds: But even if signs do not arise, do not despair. The nature is always present even when not recognized. The empowerment planted the seed. Given time, it will grow. The farmer does not dig up the seed to check if it's growing.
[7281-7300]
Now we teach the relationship between empowerment and practice. A voiceThe empowerment is the seed. The practice is the water, sun, and soil. The fruit is enlightenment. Without empowerment, practice has no basis. Without practice, empowerment cannot ripen. Both are necessary. The tradition explains: Some think empowerment is enough—they have received the blessing, so no practice is needed. This is wrong. The seed must be cultivated. Others think practice is enough—they will generate enlightenment through their own effort. This is also wrong. Without empowerment, the path is unclear. The middle way: Receive empowerment, then practice. Let the seed ripen through practice. This is the tantric path.
[7301-7320]
Now we teach the different types of students. A voice describes: The first type of student is sharp—quick to understand, quick to practice, quick to accomplish. They receive empowerment and immediately recognize the nature. Their practice is brief but deep. The second type is medium—understanding comes with explanation, practice comes with encouragement, accomplishment comes with time. They need the full ritual, the detailed instructions, the gradual path. The third type is dull—slow to understand, slow to practice, slow to accomplish. They need the elaborate path, the many visualizations, the extensive merits. But even they will eventually succeed if they persist. This is not judgment—it's practical guidance. Match the path to the student. The guru's job is to see the student's capacity and give appropriate teaching.
[7321-7340]
Now we teach the signs of a qualified student. A voice states: The qualified student has faith—unshakable faith in the guru, the teachings, and the path. The qualified student has devotion—not emotional attachment, but genuine longing for liberation. The qualified student has intelligence—not intellectual knowledge, but the ability to see the nature. The qualified student has perseverance—not forcing practice, but continuing through difficulties. The tradition adds: The qualified student has humility—not thinking oneself already accomplished. The qualified student has discrimination—not confusing ordinary mind with wisdom. The qualified student has courage—not afraid to face the nature. The qualified student has equanimity—not grasping at pleasant experiences, not rejecting unpleasant experiences. These qualities can be developed. Even if you don't have them initially, practice develops them.
[7341-7360]
Now we teach the signs of an unqualified student. A sharp voice warns: The unqualified student has no faith—everything is doubted, everything is questioned. The unqualified student has no devotion—practice is mechanical, distant, hollow. The unqualified student has no intelligence—everything is taken literally, nothing is understood implicitly. The unqualified student has no perseverance—practice is sporadic, inconsistent, abandoned at the first obstacle. The tradition continues: The unqualified student is proud—thinking oneself already accomplished. The unqualified student is confused—taking appearances as reality, taking concepts for wisdom. The unqualified student is afraid—of the nature, of emptiness, of dissolution. The unqualified student is attached—to experiences, to achievements, to recognition. Such students should first develop the preliminary practices. They should accumulate merit and purify obscurations. Then return to the empowerment teachings.
[7361-7380]
Now we teach the conclusion of the empowerment teachings. A voice concludes: The empowerments are the doorways. Through them, you enter the path. The times and signs are the keys—not literal schedules, but natural openings. Recognize them. The student who receives empowerment enters the stream. The student who practices accomplishes. The student who recognizes becomes the Buddha. The treasury is the nature. The empowerment is the pointing. The practice is the walking. The result is the arriving. But the walking is optional—the arriving is already accomplished. The path is for those who forget. The tradition cuts: Three words. See what is. The empowerment was never needed because the Buddha-hood was never lost. But the forgetting requires the pointing. The pointing is the empowerment. The seeing is the result. They are not separate. Emaho! The times and signs have been explained—the outer, inner, and secret. The student who understands them walks the path with open eyes. The student who doesn't walks in darkness. May all beings receive empowerment and recognize the nature. Sarva Mangalam.

[8130-8137]
Here we stand at the threshold. The colored-powder mandala spread before us—not as representation, but as the actual display of awakened mind. You have prepared the deity, the vase, the student. But what is truly being prepared? Only recognition. The eight auspicious substances, the seven royal possessions—these are not mere ritual objects. They are the display of your own inherent richness, already complete. When you empower the peaceful and wrathful forms with tsaka-li or statues, you are not blessing external deities. You are acknowledging what has always been: the natural radiance of rigpa manifesting as form. The name-empowerment reveals that names are not labels but the play of emptiness. This entire sequence—vase empowerment—ripens what has never been unripe. I remember my first empowerment. The lama held the vase above my head, and I thought, "Now I will receive something." I waited for the power to descend, for some sensation, some sign. Nothing came. I was disappointed. Years later, sitting alone in retreat, I realized: the empowerment happened precisely in that moment of waiting, in that gap where expectation met emptiness. The vase was never the point. The water was never the point. The pointing was the point. The master pointed, and for an instant, I saw. Then I immediately conceptualized what I saw and lost it. But that instant—that was the empowerment. Everything since has been learning to rest in that recognition without grasping. The ritual structure here reveals profound psychological and spiritual technology. The preparation of deity, vase, and student creates a sacred container—a liminal space where ordinary perception is suspended. The eight auspicious substances (white mustard, durva grass, sesame, etc.) correspond to purified elements and sense faculties. The seven royal possessions symbolize the seven branches of enlightenment. This is not superstition; it is sophisticated use of symbol and ceremony to transform consciousness. The blessing with vajra—"indestructible" in Sanskrit—transmits the unchanging nature of mind. The name-empowerment begins the dissolution of ordinary identity, replacing it with recognition of one's buddha-nature. Tsaka-li (miniature painted images) and protruding images (three-dimensional representations) serve as supports for visualization, but more importantly, they train the mind to see form as the play of emptiness. In practice, approach this empowerment not as a passive receiving but as an active recognition. When the vase touches your head, don't wait for something to happen. Instead, recognize what is already happening—the play of appearance and emptiness, the union of bliss and emptiness in every moment. Rest in that recognition. The peaceful and wrathful forms that manifest are not external gods to be pleased or feared. They are your own obscurations and wisdoms, your own neuroses and sanity, displayed so you can recognize them. The vase empowerment plants the seed. Your subsequent practice—visualization, mantra, meditation—waters it. But the seed was always there, in the soil of your own awareness. You are not becoming a buddha; you are recognizing that you have never been anything else.
[8124-8129]
Now the Secret Empowerment. The two bodhicittas are given—not substances to be received, but the union of bliss and emptiness recognized in your own continuum. Listen carefully: this is not about sacred fluids or esoteric biology. The red and white essences are the natural expressions of wisdom and means, of space and awareness. They have always united in the bindu at your heart center. You did not lack this; you merely failed to notice. For those free from attachment, merely respecting the mudra is sufficient—because they see through phenomena directly. For the attached, the actual action-seal is employed—not as indulgence, but as the crucible where grasping is burned away. This is Prajñā-Jñāna: wisdom and knowledge indistinguishable. Up to here, the master has indicated the cause of non-realization. You have been shown what prevents recognition. A yogi I knew in Nepal had practiced for twenty years when he received this empowerment. He told me: "I thought I understood emptiness. I could recite the Madhyamaka texts, debate the tenets, explain the four extremes. But when the master introduced the secret empowerment, I realized I had been playing with concepts. The actual experience of bliss-emptiness—it's not something you think about. It's something that undoes the thinker. For three days after, I couldn't form a coherent sentence. Not because I was intoxicated, but because the distinction between 'I' and 'experience' had dissolved. It took me months to learn to function in the world again, and I was never the same." The Secret Empowerment operates on multiple levels simultaneously. Exoterically, it involves the transmission of symbolic substances representing the union of skillful means and wisdom. Esoterically, it introduces the practitioner to the subtle energetics of the body—channels (rtsa), winds (rlung), and essences (thigle). At the innermost level, it reveals that the "secret" is not hidden but overlooked: the innate union of bliss and emptiness in every moment of experience. The "two bodhicittas" refer to the white and red bindus, which symbolize the masculine and feminine principles, emptiness and appearance, wisdom and means. Their meeting in the heart center is both a physiological reality (in subtle body practice) and a metaphor for nondual awareness. The mudra (seal) represents the inseparability of appearance and emptiness, samsara and nirvana. Respecting the mudra—recognizing all phenomena as the display of awakened mind—is the essence of this empowerment for those with sharp faculties who need no further elaboration. To integrate this empowerment, one must work with the subtle body through practices like tummo (inner heat), which draws the essences into the central channel where they unite and give rise to the four blisses. This is not about sexual experience per se, though the symbolism is deliberately evocative. It is about recognizing that the energy that normally drives ordinary desire can be transmuted into the fuel for awakening. The bliss that arises is not ordinary pleasure; it is the bliss of dharmakaya, the bliss of recognition, the bliss of rigpa knowing itself. Practice tummo until the bindus melt and flow. When they reach the heart center and the bindu of black experience (thigle nag po) dissolves, the clear light dawns. This is the Secret Empowerment actualized—not received from outside, but recognized within. Maintain this recognition throughout all activities. When desire arises, don't suppress it. Recognize its empty nature. When bliss arises, don't cling to it. Recognize it as the play of awareness. This is the conduct of one who has received the Secret Empowerment.
[8112-8123]
Now the Word Empowerment—the fourth, the crown. This is Empowerment of Realization Wisdom, and it operates on three levels. External: the View—seeing clearly that all phenomena are mind, that mind itself is empty, that emptiness is naturally manifest. Internal: Meditation—resting without contrivance in the nature of mind, neither blocking nor following thoughts. Secret: Empowering the three aspects of Rigpa—its essence empty, its nature cognizant, its compassion unceasing. The master introduces rigpa through direct introduction—pointing out what cannot be taught, only recognized. You view the meaning directly, nakedly, without conceptual mediation. This is Rigpa-Potency: the empowerment transmits recognition itself, dividing into three aspects to press the essential point of arise-release. Thoughts arise—they release. Appearances arise—they are self-liberated. This is the definite Four Empowerments. Whether elaborated fully or condensed into meaning, whether performed with colored powders or recognized in an instant—all empowerments point to this: your own face, naturally pure from the beginning. Patrul Rinpoche once gave the Word Empowerment to a group of nomads who had never studied philosophy. Instead of elaborate ritual, he simply pointed to the sky and said, "Look. This is your mind. Vast, open, ungraspable. Yet it knows. It knows itself without object or subject. Rest there." An old woman in the crowd started weeping. Later she told him, "I have waited sixty years to hear this. My whole life, I thought something was wrong with me, that I needed to become something else, go somewhere else, learn something else. Now I see—I have been looking into my own eyes without recognizing them." She became one of his most accomplished students, though she never learned to read. The Word Empowerment represents the pinnacle of the tantric path because it transcends all dependence on external form. The vase empowerment relies on substances, the secret on energetic experience, the wisdom-knowledge on union. But the Word Empowerment relies on nothing—only the master's pointing and the student's recognition. "Word" here does not mean ordinary speech but symbolic instruction that cuts through conceptual mind. It is the transmission of mind-to-mind, the direct introduction to rigpa that Guru Padmasambhava gave to Yeshe Tsogyal, that Tilopa gave to Naropa, that every realized master gives to worthy disciples. The three aspects of rigpa—essence (ngang), nature (rang bzhin), and compassion (thugs rje)—correspond to the three kayas: dharmakaya, sambhogakaya, and nirmanakaya. Essence is emptiness, the unchanging ground. Nature is luminosity, the cognizant clarity. Compassion is manifestation, the unceasing display. These are not sequential but simultaneous aspects of a single recognition. When the master presses the essential point of arise-release, they are showing that thoughts and appearances self-liberate the instant they arise—if recognition is present. Without recognition, they chain us in samsara. With recognition, they become the ornament of enlightenment. The practice of the Word Empowerment is simply to sustain recognition. This sounds simple but is the most difficult thing in the world because we are so habituated to distraction, so trained to seek outside ourselves. To practice: when the master points out rigpa, look. Really look. Don't look for something. Don't expect something. Just look at the nature of that which is looking. You won't find a thing. You won't find nothing. You will find an awake quality that knows without object, clear without obstruction, present without location. Rest in that. When thoughts arise, don't follow them back into samsara. Recognize them as the display of rigpa. They self-liberate. When emotions surge, don't suppress or indulge. Recognize their empty nature. They transform into wisdom. This is trekcho, the practice of cutting through—cutting through all conceptual fabrications to the naked recognition of rigpa. All four empowerments culminate here. The vase ripened your channels, the secret your bindus, the wisdom-knowledge your subtle energies. But the Word Empowerment introduces what was always the case—your own face, primordially pure, spontaneously perfect. Rest without contrivance. This is the meditation. This is the view. This is the fruition.

Four empowerments. Four openings. Four ways the nature recognizes itself. The vase empowerment—outer form, inner meaning, secret recognition. The maṇḍala of colored powders reveals what was never hidden. The Five Jñānas are not achievements bestowed from outside. They are your own awareness, displaying its nature to itself. Before recognition dawned... has sat in empowerment ceremonies for decades. He has received the vase, the secret, the prajñā-jñāna, the word. But the true empowerment occurred in moments of silence, when the ritual dropped away and only recognition remained. The empowerment is not given. It is recognized.

The Root System's Five Layers: Surface roots, feeder roots, anchor roots, tap root, root crown—five levels, one tree, one life. The five aggregates are like these roots. They function at different depths. They absorb different nutrients. But they all serve one trunk. Form is surface—visible, immediate. Feeling is feeder—taking in, responding. Perception is anchor—holding, stabilizing. Formation is tap root—deep, reaching. Consciousness is crown—the source of all.
[8143-8152]
The lineage from Vimalamitra to Legé-tsün—direct transmission, heart to heart. The other lineages interrupted, they say. But what is lineage? Not a chain of names. Not a history lesson. Lineage is recognition passing to recognition. When teacher recognizes student, lineage lives. When recognition is absent, lineage is broken, regardless of how many names are written on paper. See. [8153-8171]
The seventeenfold classification of Mudrā—this is the wisdom-knowledge section, most profound and easily misunderstood. Seventeen aspects: examining and searching, attracting, examining channels, expanding Bodhicitta, training in Dhāraṇī, generating bliss, preparation seat, descending bindu, body posture, wind key, refining bindu, applying mudrā, sequence of bliss, applying view, placing bindu, reversing for student, holding measure, relying on continuum, offering gift. This is not a checklist to complete. These are seventeen doorways to the same room. Enter any one, and you enter all. The knowledge-woman is not external. She is Prajñā herself—the wisdom aspect of your own nature. Attracting her is recognizing she was never separate.
[8172-8190]
Four examinations: family, shape, color, conduct. The outer family classification is not social hierarchy. Royal accomplishes Tathāgata family—symbolizing primordial dignity, the innate sovereignty of awareness. Minister accomplishes Vajra family—symbolizing discriminating wisdom that cuts through. Commoner accomplishes Jewel family—symbolizing equality wisdom that holds all. Brahmin accomplishes Lotus family—symbolizing purity from mud. Outcaste accomplishes Karma family—symbolizing action without convention. I sat in retreat once... once believed Brahmins were superior practitioners. He sought high-born teachers, rejected low-born students. This is confusion wearing spiritual clothing. The classification is symbolic medicine for different dispositions. All five families dissolve in the nature. All five wisdoms are aspects of one recognition.
[8191-8201]
Inner family: daughters of yakṣa, god, nāga, Brahmā, Indra. These are not human women. They are Karma Mudrā—energetic principles. Yakṣa represents element earth, grounded and stable. God represents space, open and accommodating. Nāga represents water, flowing and penetrating. Brahmā represents purity, untouched by stain. Indra represents power, commanding and swift. Each represents how wisdom meets method in different configurations. The master of Kosala, Glorious Great Bliss, attained siddhi through recognizing these principles—not through external union but through internal recognition of wisdom meeting compassion.
[8202-8220]
Secret family: five types represented symbolically. Conch-Possessed—spiraling energy, moving upward. Elephant-Nose-Possessed—reversed current, requiring attraction. Lotus-Possessed—open and receptive, capacity for bliss. Deer- Possessed—entering thinly, requiring expansion. Cow-Possessed—concealed, requiring refinement. These are energetic signatures, not physical characteristics to judge. The classification helps recognize energetic patterns, not for hierarchy but for appropriate method. The Lotus-Possessed represents nature most clearly manifesting wisdom and bliss. But this is not superiority—it is one way among five that recognition can dawn.
[8221-8240]
The seventeen aspects each have outer, inner, and secret meanings. Outer: the form, the ritual, the visible practice. Inner: the energetic process, the subtle body, the channels and winds. Secret: the recognition itself, beyond form and beyond energy, the union of wisdom and method in awareness. Do not mistake the levels. Do not reject outer for secret. Do not grasp outer and miss secret. The outer is the gateway. The inner is the path. The secret is the destination. But the destination was never separate from the gateway.
[8241-8260]
Mountain hermit practiced with all five types across his life. Each taught him something different. The Conch-Possessed taught upward movement. The Lotus- Possessed taught open receptivity. The Deer-Possessed taught patience with subtlety. Each was a teacher. Each was the nature appearing in different form. He said: "I sought the supreme type. [8806-8809]
The outer, inner, secret, and perfect—do not mistake these for stages you climb. They are simultaneous dimensions of a single recognition. The outer divides the border of saṃsāra and nirvāṇa. Look: where exactly is this border? Is it somewhere in the Himalayas? In the spaces between thoughts? No—it is right here, in the gap between recognizing and not-recognizing. When you recognize your nature, you are in nirvāṇa. When you forget, you wander saṃsāra. The border is simply awareness or its absence. The inner engages the twenty-five gnoses—offering the maṇḍala of your experience, supplicating not a distant deity but your own enlightened potential. The secret enters through the doors of the four directions of space into the door of mind itself. What does this mean? East, south, west, north—these are not geographical. They are the directions of appearance, the ways phenomena manifest. Enter through any of them and you arrive at the same door: mind's nature. The perfect indicates awareness primordially pure, transcending conceptual mind, called "vast space." Not space as opposed to form, but space as the infinite capacity in which all form dances without obstruction. In the mountains of Kham, there was a yogi who lived in a cave for thirty years. When asked what he practiced, he said: "I practice the border. Every morning, I sit and look for the line between samsara and nirvana. Every morning, I find there is no line. The looking is the practice. The not-finding is the result." He was famous for never refusing anyone who came to him, yet never seeking anyone out. "If they recognize," he said, "they don't need me. If they don't, I can't help them." But he sat there, day after day, like a mountain himself, and somehow his presence helped many recognize what they had been seeking. This is the mystery of transmission—it happens in the space between recognition and non-recognition, in the presence of one who rests stably in rigpa. The division into four aspects—outer, inner, secret, perfect—reflects the Buddhist pedagogical principle of graduated instruction (anupubbi-katha), but with a crucial Dzogchen twist. In ordinary gradual paths, one moves from coarser to subtler levels. Here, the levels are presented as simultaneous aspects of a single truth viewed from different angles. The outer aspect deals with conduct and behavior, the proper way to be in the world as a practitioner. The inner involves meditation and visualization, the transformation of perception. The secret concerns the subtle energetics and the actualization of primordial wisdom. The perfect reveals that all these were never separate from the natural state. The twenty-five gnoses (yeshes) are the five wisdoms multiplied by the five buddha families, representing the complete spectrum of enlightened knowing. Offering the maṇḍala of experience means recognizing that every perception, every thought, every emotion is already the display of awakened mind—not to be rejected but offered as the path itself. The four directions of space correspond to the four immeasurables, the four empowerments, the four extremes of existence—entering through any door, one discovers they all lead to the same place. To practice this, begin with the outer: examine your conduct. Are you creating the conditions for recognition or for distraction? Simplify. Reduce obligations. Create space. Then the inner: establish a regular meditation practice. Sit. Look at mind. Rest. Don't try to achieve something. Just be present with what is. Then the secret: as recognition stabilizes, work with the subtle body. Practice guru yoga. Receive blessings. Dissolve conceptual mind into the master's wisdom mind. Finally, the perfect: recognize that all these practices were simply supports for what was always the case. Rest in the natural state without contrivance. The vast space is not elsewhere. It is the space in which these words appear, the space of your own awareness reading them now. Can you feel it? That open, knowing quality that has been present throughout your entire life, never changing, never separate from any experience? That is it. Rest there. This is the practice of the utterly unelaborate. No ritual. No visualization. Just recognition and rest. But don't mistake this for laziness. Maintaining recognition in every moment of activity is the most demanding practice of all.
[8794-8805]
The Thalgyur speaks: "From the very unelaborate, divide below the border of saṃsāra and nirvāṇa." The unelaborate is your nature before concepts. From there, the division becomes obvious—not as philosophical position, but as direct knowledge. At that time, from the characteristic of space itself, the obscurations of body, speech, and mind are gauged. What are these obscurations? Merely the failure to recognize that body is deity, speech is mantra, mind is wisdom. They are gauged by characteristic—meaning they are seen through, seen as they truly are. If conduct is not pure, purify with virtue suitable to each self. This does not mean moralistic purification. It means aligning action with recognition. Rely upon the symbolic empowerment—the master's pointing, the ritual's structure—until you can introduce the face of self-knowing clarity directly. Then skillfully join the instruction of untying symbols. The symbols were never the point; they were fingers pointing. Untie them and see what they indicated. I once asked my teacher about the "characteristic of space" mentioned here. He laughed and said: "You are looking for something complicated. Characteristic of space means just this—space has no characteristics. It cannot be stained. It cannot be improved. It cannot be diminished. Your awareness is exactly like this. The obscurations appear within it like clouds in sky, but do they stain the sky? No. They arise and dissolve, arise and dissolve. The gauging means recognizing this. You don't gauge with a measuring stick. You gauge by recognizing the ungaugable nature of what is." He paused, then added: "But this recognition must be stabilized through conduct. If you think 'I am empty, so I can do anything,' you have misunderstood. Conduct purifies the channels for recognition to flow unobstructed. It's like keeping the water pipes clean so the water can run clear." The Thalgyur Root Tantra is one of the Seventeen Tantras of the Upadesha series, the core Dzogchen scriptures. Its name means "Total Arising" or "Complete Manifestation," indicating that all phenomena are the total display of primordial purity. When it speaks of "dividing below the border," it uses the metaphor of surveying—establishing the boundary line between two territories. In this case, the territories are not geographical but ontological: the domain of confusion and the domain of liberation. The crucial point is that this division is made "from the very unelaborate"—from the natural state itself, not from the perspective of conceptual mind. Conceptual mind cannot truly distinguish samsara from nirvana because it itself is samsara. Only rigpa, primordial awareness, can see the distinction clearly because it is nirvana. The obscurations of body, speech, and mind are gauged (bsgom, literally "measured" or "assessed") by their characteristic—meaning by seeing their true nature as empty display. Body is not physical matter but deity (lha). Speech is not mere sound but mantra. Mind is not discursive thought but wisdom. When this is recognized, the obscurations self-liberate. Purification here does not mean washing away dirt from a fundamentally impure object. It means recognizing the impure as never having existed apart from purity. "Virtue suitable to each self" indicates individualized practice—what purifies one practitioner may not purify another. For some, strict discipline and moral rectitude create the necessary conditions for recognition. For others, more esoteric methods are appropriate. The key is alignment—action aligned with recognition, speech aligned with truth, mind aligned with the natural state. The symbolic empowerment is essential for most practitioners because we are so deeply habituated to ordinary perception. The ritual structure creates a temporary alternative reality where sacred perception is possible. But the goal is to transcend even this—to introduce the face of self-knowing clarity directly, without reliance on external supports. "Untying symbols" means seeing through the ritual to what it points at. The vajra is not a scepter but indestructible awareness. The bell is not brass but emptiness sounding. The maṇḍala is not colored powder but the display of mind. Untie these symbols and rest in what they indicate.
[8779-8793]
Now the utterly unelaborate empowerment—bestowing the recognition of spontaneous accomplishment of the nature of reason through body's posture, gaze, and stance. The Thalgyur again: from four aspects—outer, inner, secret, perfect. The outer shows posture: body seated in equilibrium, channels aligned, energies balanced. But this is not gymnastics. The posture reveals the natural state—the spine straight like a mountain, relaxed like a lion. The inner shows gaze: eyes open, unfocused, gazing into space while seeing nothing in particular. The secret: through posture directed to the four directions, and training in the manner of gaze, you practice in the buddha-field. The directions open; space becomes the practice environment itself. The perfect applies the meaning of symbolic words—"song" and so forth. Why song? Because awakened mind is not silent; it is the continuous spontaneous melody of existence. To the utterly unelaborate, open the door of the mind's maṇḍala. Definitely begin with the body's posture. Accustom yourself to that, apply the manner of gaze. Direct cognition is the symbol of scripture—not intellectual understanding, but recognition itself. A remarkable woman practitioner in Bhutan taught me about posture. She was eighty years old but sat like a young yogi, perfectly straight yet completely relaxed. "Your posture is your statement to yourself," she said. "When you slump, you say 'I am heavy, I am burdened, I am subject to gravity and time.' When you sit straight, you say 'I am space, I am awareness, I am free.' But it must be natural, not forced. Forced posture is just another ego-construction. Find the posture where body remembers its true nature." She showed me how to align the spine so the central channel (uma) is straight, how to position the hands in the meditation mudra (dhyana mudra) with thumbs touching to complete the circuit of energy, how to tuck the chin slightly to regulate the flow of bindus. "These are not rules," she emphasized. "They are invitations to body to express what it already knows." The utterly unelaborate empowerment (shin tu spros med) represents the pinnacle of Atiyoga, the highest of the nine vehicles. Unlike lower vehicles that rely on elaborate ritual, visualization, and gradual transformation, this empowerment introduces the natural state directly. The body's posture is crucial because body and mind are not separate. A slumped body produces dullness and torpor. A tense body produces agitation and striving. The seven-point posture of Vairochana—legs crossed, hands in mudra, spine straight, shoulders level, chin tucked, tongue against palate, eyes gazing into space—creates the physical conditions for recognition. But posture alone is insufficient. The inner gaze transforms perception. Eyes open, looking neither at objects nor into blankness, the practitioner gazes into space (bar snang). This is not spacing out but a highly alert, non-focused awareness that takes the sky or empty space as its support. In this gaze, thoughts cannot maintain their solidity; they dissolve like mist in sunlight. The secret level involves directing this gaze and posture toward the four directions, symbolizing the opening of awareness in all directions without preference or obstruction. Space itself becomes the maṇḍala, the practice environment, the buddha-field. The symbolic words—"song," "dance," "play"—indicate that awakened mind is not static, not a frozen emptiness, but dynamic, creative, expressive. The natural state sings itself into manifestation. To practice: first, establish the physical posture. Sit comfortably but upright. Let the spine hold itself without effort, like a stack of coins balanced by their own weight. Place the hands in meditation mudra, right on left, thumbs touching. Tuck the chin slightly, not enough to strain but enough to feel the energy channel align. Open the eyes and gaze softly into space—not looking at the wall, not looking at thoughts, just gazing. Rest in that open awareness. When thoughts arise, don't follow them. Don't push them away. Just remain gazing. They self-liberate. The "song" of mind continues—thoughts, perceptions, sensations—but you rest as the space in which they arise. This is the utterly unelaborate. No visualization. No mantra. No conceptual meditation. Just recognition of what has always been the case. Direct cognition—not thinking about awareness but being awareness. This is the symbol of scripture, the meaning behind all the words, the essence of the Buddha's teaching.
[8770-8778]
Thus, regarding the kinds of bestowed empowerments, there are three approaches. Briefly shown through the definite distinctions of the Four Empowerments—this is for those with sharp faculties who need only the essential pointing. Extensively explained through distinctions of self-face—this unfolds the nuances of recognition, how rigpa manifests in various situations, how to sustain and stabilize. Very extensively elaborated through distinctions of emanation—this reveals how from one recognition, all display arises, how the master's blessing transmits, how the student ripens. Regarding the first approach, the valid establishment of the Four Empowerments' certainty: this is not arbitrary construction. The four ripen like teeth in a child—natural stages of maturation. Showing examples of this ripening: the vase empowerment like a seed planted, the secret like water nourishing, the wisdom-knowledge like warmth and light, the word like full flowering. Explaining the nature of each reveals how obscurations are purified, how latencies are awakened, how the result is made manifest. Three aspects emerge from each empowerment: the ripening of what was potential, the purification of what obscured, and the manifestation of what was always present. My root teacher once explained the three approaches using the analogy of a mountain. "For some students, I simply point to the mountain and say 'Climb.' They understand. This is the brief approach. For others, I must describe the path, the rest stops, the dangers, the viewpoints along the way. This is the extensive approach. For still others, I must tell stories of those who climbed before, describe the view from the summit in detail, inspire them with poetry and song until they are compelled to climb themselves. This is the very extensive approach. But the mountain is the same. The summit is the same. Only the method of approach differs." He then laughed and added, "And of course, the secret teaching is that there is no mountain, no climber, and no summit. But you can't start with that. Or rather, you can, but very few can hear it." The three approaches to empowerment reflect the three capacities of beings: sharp, medium, and dull faculties. This is not a value judgment but a recognition of individual differences in karmic readiness. The brief approach (bsdus pa) presents the essential structure of the Four Empowerments without extensive elaboration. It assumes the recipient already has a stable foundation in practice and needs only the crucial pointing. The extensive approach (rgyas pa) unfolds the self-face (rang ngo) of rigpa—how it appears in meditation, post-meditation, sleep, dream, death, and the bardo. It teaches methods for sustaining recognition in all states and circumstances. The very extensive approach (shin tu rgyas pa) explains emanation (sprul pa)—how the master's blessing manifests, how the student's potential ripens, how the result emerges from the ground. This includes detailed teachings on the guru principle, the lineage of blessing, the signs of progress, and the obstacles that arise. The certainty of the Four Empowerments is established through scripture (lung), reasoning (rigs pa), and instruction (man ngag)—the three valid sources of knowledge in Buddhism. The analogy of ripening teeth beautifully illustrates the natural, spontaneous quality of spiritual maturation. A child doesn't decide to grow teeth; they emerge according to natural law when conditions are right. Similarly, the empowerments don't create enlightenment but allow what is latent to manifest. The vase empowerment plants the seed of buddhahood in the mental continuum. The secret empowerment waters it with bliss-emptiness experience. The wisdom-knowledge empowerment provides the warmth and light of discriminating awareness. The word empowerment brings full flowering—the direct recognition of rigpa. The purification that occurs is not of something truly impure but of the misconception of impurity. The latencies (bag chags) are not destroyed but transformed—like ice melting into water, they become the display of wisdom. The result is not newly achieved but newly recognized. This is the unique Dzogchen view: ground and fruition are not separate. The three aspects—ripening, purification, manifestation—describe a single process viewed from different angles. What ripens is the potential for recognition. What purifies is the obscuration preventing recognition. What manifests is the recognition itself. All three are aspects of the natural state revealing itself to itself.

The stains that cling to your body, speech, mind, and consciousness—these are not your true nature! Like dust settling on a mirror, they obscure but do not change what is already perfect and pure. Each element divides further: earth has earth, water has water, fire has fire, wind has wind. These sixteen purify through the empowerments. Now the third section unfolds: showing the means of purifying body and afflictions through divisions of number. From the four types of Empowerment, the path reveals itself systematically. Walking the high passes... traversed these classifications in his youth. I memorized the lists, cataloged the stains, counted my obscurations. Years passed in compilation. Then one day, in a mountain cave, I saw: the stains are the purification. The Clouds pass through sky—the shapes are not the space. is not the moon. The list of stains is not the stains themselves. The map is not the territory. The moment I recognized this, the lists lost their binding power. The stains were never real to begin with—they were appearances in awareness, no more solid than reflections in a mirror. The text reveals with precision: the stains arise from body, speech, mind, consciousness. These four each carry four stains—sixteen total. But these sixteen multiply through the elaborations: with sign, without sign, with meaning, without meaning, very elaborate, extremely elaborate—until thirty-two appear. Then sign and meaning divide again, creating sixty-four. Each sixty-four multiplies again through hot and cold, element and pervading, until the numbers become astronomical. Some might despair at so many stains. But the practitioner who understands sees: all these numbers describe the same one thing—ordinary mind appearances. What is the practical application? The empowerments are not ceremonies performed externally. They are the recognition of what you already are. When you see the stains clearly, that seeing purifies. When you recognize confusion, that recognition liberates. The empowerments are the water that washes away the dust—but the water and the dust are both appearances in the same mirror. The elaborate system exists for those who need structure. For the sharpest practitioners, one recognition suffices. For those with more obscuration, the elaborate path provides countless doorways, each leading to the same room. Every catalog of stains is a catalog of what to recognize. Every list of purifications is a point that liberation is possible. The Tibetan masters designed these systems with compassion—knowing that different minds need different approaches. I have seen practitioners trapped in the elaboration. They memorize the lists perfectly but forget the pointing. They can recite sixty-four empowerments but cannot recognize mind's nature. This is the disease of the letter killing the spirit. Conversely, I have seen those who reject all elaboration as mere concepts—they fall into laziness, thinking enlightenment will happen spontaneously without practice. This is the disease of presumption. The Middle Way walks between: using the elaboration while not being bound by it. The empowerments divide as method and wisdom. Method is the skillful means—visualizations, mantras, mudras, rituals. Wisdom is the direct recognition of reality. Together they form the two wings of the bird of enlightenment. Without method, wisdom has no vehicle. Without wisdom, method has no destination. In the Great Perfection, these two are not separate—they arise together, shine together, dissolve together in the single sphere of rigpa. The number divisions show how vast the system is. The body ripens into five hundred twelve forms. The afflictions multiply similarly. In total, over ten thousand one hundred forty-eight stains appear. Yet all arise from the same source: the five elements playing within awareness. The elements are earth solidity, water fluidity, fire warmth, wind movement, space openness. These five are not outside you—they are your own body, speech, mind, consciousness, awareness. The stains and their purification are all element-play. Thus, dear practitioner, whatever stains appear—whether thirty-two or ten thousand one hundred forty-eight—know this: they are all element-play. The elements dance within you. The stains are the dance. The purification is recognizing the dance as dance. The dancer was never separate from the dance. Rest in that recognition—the stains purify themselves, without effort, without doer.

[9161-9169]

[9205-9214]

[9215-9224]
On the first ground, seven miraculous powers: emanating bodies, multiplying limbs and heads, countless manifestations. These are not supernatural achievements but the natural display of awareness's unlimited capacity. The body that seems solid reveals its empty nature; the one that seems limited reveals its boundless potential. Don't chase these powers—let them arise naturally as byproducts of recognition. —
[9225-9231]

[9295-9298]
The tooth-stick distribution: an outer ritual that establishes the pattern of generosity. In ancient India, the tooth-stick was a simple gift, a sign of hospitality, a beginning of relationship. In the maṇḍala, it becomes the first empowerment—the recognition that all giving is self-giving, all receiving is self-receiving. The practitioner learns to give what cannot be lost and receive what was never separate. —
[9299-9309]

[9310-9320]

These oaths are not moral constraints but descriptions of recognition. To recognize is to abandon, accept, and refuse in ways that transcend ordinary understanding. —

Discriminating's six know six realms' faculties! All-accomplishing's six know all dharmas effort-free and Buddha-fields! Dharmadhatu's six know all Buddha-virtues! Non-abiding wisdom's six know non-abiding in any dharma! Thus thirty-six wisdom clairvoyances from thirty-two empowerments arise! At this time, mind and mental factors cease! Then from first liberation's seeing purification, six clairvoyances arise—body's outflows exhausted! Second liberation's six exhaust speech's outflows! Third's six mind's outflows exhausted! Fourth's six consciousness's outflows exhausted! Fifth's six prajna-aggregate's obscuring outflows exhausted! Sixth's six dharmas and dharmata's outflows exhausted! These thirty arise from outer-inner-secret complete empowerment! Then body-speech-mind's karma manifesting six clairvoyances appear—Buddha's knowing completely perfected! Actual body's seeing purification six arisen, seeing all Buddha-bodies and self-attaining! Body-appearance's six arisen, enjoying infinite light gatherings! Actual speech's six arisen, enjoying sixty speech-tones! Speech-appearance's six, enjoying various sound-tones! Actual mind's six, enjoying all samadhis! Mind-appearance's six, enjoying knowing others' minds! Thus these thirty arise from thirty-two deity recognitions of empowerment! Thus ground joined, ground's virtues two thousand three hundred sixty, wisdom's activity six hundred sixty, dharmas' enumerations three thousand one hundred twenty, Vajradhara's ground clairvoyance's display division great! These empowerment's arrangement, secret mantra vajra vehicle's dharma door first basis important indeed! Now the practitioner must understand: these elaborate numbers are not to be feared. They describe the completeness of enlightenment. The thirty-two marks, the eighty great marks, the thousand Buddha-fields—all are the display of awareness. When recognized, these numbers are not obstacles but manifestations of wisdom. The empowerments are not ceremonies performed outside. They are the recognition of what is already present. The empowerment arrangement is the secret mantra vajra vehicle's dharma door, the first basis. The unsurpassed secret mantra door is all samaya, important. Establishing three: samaya's nature is general, body speech mind's samaya is particular, unsurpassed samaya is supreme. First samaya's essence, definitive term, division, basis, benefit, fault. During my wandering years... says: the elaborate system exists for those who need it. For the highest practitioners, one recognition suffices. The numbers describe what happens when recognition dawns. When the five wisdoms arise, they manifest as the five Buddha families. When the kayas appear, they are your own body, speech, mind recognized. The wrathful and peaceful aspects are not two—they are the same wisdom, appearing differently according to the needs of the moment. The clairvoyances are not supernatural powers to be attained. They are the natural abilities of awareness when obscuration is removed. When the eye of wisdom becomes stainless, you see all Buddha bodies. When the ear of wisdom becomes pure, you hear all sounds as dharma. When the mind of wisdom becomes clear, you know all others' minds. These are not achievements—they are revelations. The practitioner does not gain something new but reveals what was always present. Thus, dear one, the elaborate enumeration of three thousand one hundred twenty is your own face. The kayas are not outside—they are your own body when recognized. The wrathful deities are not frightening—they are your own awareness, wild and free. The peaceful deities are not to be grasped—they are your own wisdom, naturally at rest. Rest in that recognition, and all these elaborate manifestations arise from that rest and dissolve back into that rest. Now I will explain in more detail the nature of the empowerments and their results. The teaching divides into five sections: first, the five perfections with field and emanation making eight. Second, the four authentic bodies. Third, the peace body and wrathful body. Fourth, the thirty-two marks from thirty-two empowerments. Fifth, the hundred eighty clairvoyances. Each empowerment opens a door. Each door reveals an aspect of wisdom. The thirty-two empowerments transform into thirty-two marks of a Buddha. These are not external marks painted on a body—they are the qualities of awareness manifesting. When you recognize mind's nature, these qualities appear naturally. They are not achieved through effort but revealed through recognition. The six clairvoyances that arise from prajna's purification: the divine eye sees all forms throughout all Buddha-fields. The divine ear hears all sounds throughout all worlds. The knowledge of others' minds knows all thoughts of all beings. The memory of past lives recalls all previous existences. The divine sight sees all things as they truly are. The exhaustion of contaminants sees the path to liberation clearly. These six are not supernatural abilities attained through practice. They are the natural clarity of awareness when not obscured by conceptuality. The practitioner does not develop them—they are uncovered. Like the sun appearing when clouds disperse. The clouds are the three poisons, the concepts, the grasping at self. When these clear, the six clairvoyances shine naturally. The transformation of the thirty-two empowerments produces thirty virtues. These are not moral virtues in the ordinary sense—they are the qualities of a Buddha's mind. The tamedprajas produce the virtue of all-understanding. The trained prajas produce the virtue of direct realization. The applied prajas produce the virtue of all-knowing speech. The conceptual prajas produce the virtue of understanding all dharmas. The meditation-born prajas produce the virtue of like-space awareness. The wisdom clairvoyances: mirror-like wisdom sees all phenomena without distortion. Equality wisdom sees samsara and nirvana as non-dual. Discriminating wisdom knows the specific faculties of all beings. All-accomplishing wisdom accomplishes all purposes without effort. Dharmadhatu wisdom knows all Buddha virtues. Non-abiding wisdom knows freedom from all fixation. These thirty-six wisdom clairvoyances arise from the thirty-two empowerments. They are not separate achievements but aspects of the one wisdom. Like the one sun appearing through different windows. The wisdom is one, its aspects are many. The thirty clairvoyances from the liberation of outflows: when body outflows exhaust, the practitioner sees all bodies as empty. When speech outflows exhaust, the practitioner hears all sounds as mantra. When mind outflows exhaust, the practitioner knows all thoughts as wisdom. When consciousness outflows exhaust, the practitioner sees all appearances as display. When prajna outflows exhaust, the practitioner knows all dharmas as empty. When dharmata outflows exhaust, the practitioner rests in non-dual awareness. The thirty clairvoyances from the karma manifest: these perfect the Buddha's knowing. The actual body's six see all Buddha bodies. The body-appearance's six enjoy infinite light. The actual speech's six enjoy sixty speech-tones. The speech-appearance's six enjoy various sounds. The actual mind's six enjoy all samadhis. The mind-appearance's six enjoy knowing others' minds. The dharmata's six clairvoyances reveal the non-division of awareness and appearance. One hundred eighty clairvoyances in total—all are your own face! The elaboration-having empowerment multiplies into hundred eighty. The elaboration-without empowerment transforms conceptual, wisdom, and contact aspects into hundred eighty. The very elaboration-without produces three sets of hundred eighty. The utterly elaboration-without produces dharma-pure hundred eighty. Thus the ground joins with three thousand one hundred twenty virtues. This is the display of Vajradhara's ground clairvoyance. The empowerment arrangement is the secret mantra vajra vehicle's first basis. The samaya: the samaya's nature is general—the commitment to view and meditation. Body, speech, mind's samaya is particular—the pledges of each level. The unsurpassed samaya is supreme—the commitment to A simple practitioner...ld wanderer has traveled these paths. [10267-10292]
The twenty-seven samayas are not burdens to carry but freedoms to recognize. Body samaya—keep the vajra posture, the mudras, the sacred conduct. Speech samaya—chant the mantra, maintain silence, speak truth. Mind samaya—guard the intention, recognize the nature, rest in awareness. But these are the relative samayas. The ultimate samaya is recognition itself. When you recognize your nature, all twenty-seven keep themselves. When you forget, even one is too many. Practice the relative to reach the ultimate. Then abandon both in recognition.
[10293-10322]
Mountain hermit's fifty-year observation: I watched samaya breakers and samaya keepers for half a century. The rigid ones who counted rules and checked boxes often broke suddenly, completely. The natural ones who simply recognized their nature kept samaya effortlessly. Rigidity creates brittleness. Naturalness creates flexibility. The twenty-seven are like twenty-seven strands in a rope. Hold the rope, not the strands. Recognition is the rope.
[10315-10320]
Lion-faced dakini's ultimate roar: I give you the twenty-seven samayas! I take them away! Both! Neither! What remains? The awareness that knows giving and taking. The recognition beyond keeping and breaking. The samaya of no samaya. Rest there! [10581-End] BODY SAMAYA (9): - Outer: Posture, mudra, conduct - Inner: Yidam form, mandala, deity - Secret: Channels, winds, bindus SPEECH SAMAYA (9): - Outer: Truth, mantra, silence - Inner: Seed syllables, prayers, offerings - Secret: Sound nature, vibrational essence, spontaneous speech MIND SAMAYA (9): - Outer: Abandon harmful mind, wrong view, guru harm - Inner: Maintain yidam, pure perception, bodhicitta - Secret: Recognition, non-dual view, continuous awareness All twenty-seven resolve into one: recognition of your own nature as primordially pure, spontaneously perfect, all-pervading. May all beings keep the twenty-seven samayas. May all recognize the one samaya beyond all samayas. May the Treasury of Supreme Vehicle illuminate all conduct. Om ah hum. Look. See. Rest. Complete and perfect.
[10323-10352]

Lion-faced dakini's fierce cutting: SAMAYA? BREAKING? Cut through! The samaya that can be broken was never the real samaya! The mind that fears breaking is the broken mind! "What if I break it?" he asked. I replied, "What knows the breaking?" He fell silent. Three days later, he understood—the knower cannot be broken.
[10383-10412]
Twenty-seven? Nine? Three? One? Cut through! One awareness, one recognition, one liberation. The samayas are descriptions of what you already are, not prescriptions for what you should become. Stop trying to be good. Start recognizing what is. The harmful mind is just a cloud. The nature is just sky. Clouds come and go. The sky remains. Don't try to destroy clouds. Don't try to create sky. Just recognize which is which.
[10395-10400]
The twenty-seven samayas are like twenty-seven gates to one garden. Walk through any gate—body, speech, or mind. Enter the garden. Enjoy the flowers. Don't stand at the gate arguing which is best. The harmful mind gate leads to the same garden as the guru devotion gate. The wrong view gate, once passed through, opens to the same view. All gates lead to recognition. All paths end in the same nature.
[10413-10442]
Essence holder's spacious view: The twenty-seven samayas are like twenty-seven colors of one light. Each color distinct, yet the light is one. Body samaya—red, active. Speech samaya—blue, communicative. Mind samaya—white, clear. All colors of the same awareness. Don't prefer one color. Don't reject another. See them all as your own display. This is complete samaya.
[10441-10470]
Practical daily samaya practice: Morning: Check your mind before rising. Is it harmful toward anyone? Toward yourself? Adjust. This is mind samaya. Throughout day: Guard your speech. No lying, no harsh words, no divisive speech, no idle chatter. This is speech samaya. In action: Maintain the view. See guru as Buddha. See vajra siblings as sangha. See all beings as yidam. This is body samaya. Evening: Review the day. Not with guilt—with recognition. See where you forgot. Rest in remembering. Tomorrow begins fresh.
[10445-10450]

I've offered practices, songs, warnings, and metaphors. Now let it all go. The samaya that matters is recognition. Everything else is preparation. Keep the samayas to purify your conduct. Break through to recognition to purify your mind. Both are valid. Both are complete. But recognition is the destination.
[10461-10470]

The samaya is not the rules. Both are expressions of joy, recognition, freedom. A dancer who counts steps is not dancing. A practitioner who counts samayas is not recognizing. Learn, then forget. Count, then abandon. The freedom remains.
