Therefore. Thus. The Great Perfection presents seven ways of describing the basis. Not because there are seven grounds. Because minds need seven doors to enter what has no entrance.
[10487-10490]
First: primordially pure from the beginning. Like space unstained by the clouds that pass through it. The purity is not achieved. It is the nature (rang bzhin) of what is.
[10491-10502]
Second: spontaneously present. Like the sun that does not choose to shine, yet illuminates all. Qualities complete without cultivation. Radiance without effort.
[10503-10513]
Third: uncertain, indeterminate. Not fixed as this or that. Not captured by any concept. The awareness that refuses to be boxed. Seven blind men arguing about the elephant, each convinced they hold the truth.
[10514-10524]
Fourth: certain, established. Unchanging in its nature. While appearances transform, the ground remains. Like the ocean holding all waves without becoming the waves.
[10521-10547]
From Klongdrukpa: The basis spontaneously established from the very beginning, although not existing as a singular entity that can be grasped. When abiding as spontaneous presence, the gathering of multiplicity appears as the essential nature. When abiding as uncertain, the aspect of mind that transforms appears. When abiding as certainty, remembrance without movement. When abiding as transformable, mind through effort. When abiding as essence of what-is, whatever appears appears as its own nature. When abiding as variegated, various individual manners. When abiding as primordially pure, stains appear as primordially non-existent. All these arise from stages of mind's own delusion, while one's own face is primordially pure.
[10525-10535]
Fifth: transformable into anything. The mirror showing all reflections without becoming any. The basis as infinite potential, not fixed identity.
[10536-10546]
Sixth: accepting anything that arises. The ground that holds samsara and nirvana equally. Not choosing between confusion and liberation. Both are its play.
[10536-10547]
Second: demonstrating that the seven grounds that fall into conceptual extremes are faulty. Like blind men describing an elephant before them, each grasping only a part. When proponents hold tenets by fixating on one limited aspect of awareness as the complete realization, each establishing their acceptance deeply as the whole truth, they become the blind men arguing in the marketplace. Each is partially correct. Each is completely wrong.
[10537-10547]
Seventh: various, manifold, multi-colored. The appearance without ceasing. The variegated display that is mistaken for multiplicity. Like one crystal showing many colors—seven men seeing seven different elephants.
[10546-10547]
The refutation is not destruction. It is widening the prison walls until they become space. Spontaneous presence does not need defense. Primordial purity does not need proof. Certainty and uncertainty are both thoughts. the ground is prior to thought. Rest there.
01 08 02 01
[10548-10553]
Spontaneous presence cannot be the ground of liberation. This is not negation—it is precision. If all were spontaneously accomplished from the beginning, who would need to practice? Who would become liberated? The path would be meaningless. The text examines each position with surgical precision. First: the position holding that the ground of samsara and nirvana is mere unceasing display. This fails upon analysis. Why? Because if rigpa were merely unceasing display without recognition, it would be unreasonable for samsara and nirvana to arise and cease without any recognition of its own face.
[10554-10563]
One who walked paths... once wandered in the mountains, thinking spontaneous presence was enough. I rested in naked awareness, letting everything display without干预. Years passed. Confusion remained. Liberation did not arrive. I studied gradual paths for years. Then forgot: recognition was always immediate. The library blazed open. The word points. The pointing liberates. Who translates? From Oddiyana's sky-treasure: concepts bloom and dissolve like lotus in fire. The distinguisher was never born!
[10564-10571]
If the basis were merely spontaneous presence, samsara and nirvana would be one. The nature is complete. The apparent complexity resolves in simplicity when recognition dawns—before analysis, already complete. Wherever samsara is, nirvana would be. Wherever nirvana is, samsara would be. The pure would be impure. The impure would be pure. The path dissolves into contradiction.
[10572-10584]
Therefore. Thus. We analyze the logical faults. Spontaneous presence as the sole basis fails under scrutiny. Not because it is wrong. Because it is incomplete. Like describing an elephant by its tail alone. The text gives logical reasons: If cause and effect were both primordially spontaneously accomplished from the very beginning without any dependence on recognition, then cause and effect would necessarily exist simultaneously as one essence, rendering all distinction meaningless. If the cause is established as samsara, the effect would clearly not be able to manifest as nirvana, for they would be identical. If samsara and nirvana were truly one essence, then samsara would necessarily follow wherever nirvana is present. And nirvana following upon samsara would cause those two to be one without distinction—an absurd consequence. Pure and impure cannot exist simultaneously as cause and effect if they are one substance. This is not philosophical hair-splitting—this is the precise medicine needed for precise diseases of view.
[10585-10608]
From Klongdrukpa: Spontaneous accomplishment being posited as the ground is truly not the correct basis. If it were, sentient beings without effort would never attain liberation. Non-recognition becomes the cause of continued obscuration. If mere awareness were sufficient for liberation, then liberation would not be distinct from ordinary existence. Like charcoal upon black earth cannot be cleaned to appear white. Cause and effect would remain separate without connection. The tantra speaks in analogies the mind can grasp. Charcoal and black earth—same nature, different appearance. You cannot wash charcoal white. Not because washing fails. Because the nature (rang bzhin) is black. Liberation requires recognition, not just presence. Samantabhadra declares: This teaching of spontaneous presence exists merely among conventional dharmas known by intellect. It is not the correct essence of the ultimate basis. Even the Primordial Buddha distinguishes between conventional description and ultimate reality. Thus it is declared: mere unceasing display cannot truly constitute the authentic recognition of realization. If cause and effect were established as truly one without distinction, then recognition and resting in one's own nature would become entirely unnecessary, rendering the direct path meaningless. To merely name unceasing display as the ground without understanding its true relation to primordial purity is not a meaning that can be genuinely understood or established through direct recognition.
[10609-10617]
Second position: uncertainty as the basis. Because awareness is not established as definite entity, it remains uncertain. Because conditions transform it, it remains without fixed nature. The Mind Section teaches: From manifold names given to uncertainty, meaning is merely labels, empty like echoes. This practitioner once loved uncertainty. It felt spacious. Liberating. No fixed views. No certainties to defend. Then he saw: uncertainty itself becomes a fixed view. The open door becomes another prison. The Semde teachings say: From the manifold names and designations given to uncertainty, the meaning too is merely labels, empty in themselves like echoes. Because the nature is not determined as singular or fixed, whatever label is applied through convention appears accordingly without inherent reality.
[10618-10631]
Refutation: If the basis were one essence, it could not be non-one—a direct contradiction. If uncertain basis were cause of samsara, it would be determined as confusion. If basis of nirvana, determined as purity. Both cannot be true. If inherently pure, impurity cannot arise. If uncertain, samsara and nirvana mix without distinction. Buddhas would revert to confusion. The basis would become mind's possession rather than nature. The logic is merciless. Each position examined finds its own destruction. This is not cruelty. It is compassion wearing the mask of destruction. The positions must die so recognition can live. Further faults: If the ground remains uncertain without any determinate ground or established nature, samsara and nirvana would mutually mix together without distinction, destroying the path and fruition. If the ground is fundamentally uncertain and changes in every regard without any stability, all sentient beings would be liberated without any effort or practice whatsoever, while fully awakened Buddhas would revert to impure confusion, once again engaging with suffering. Moreover, asserting only uncertainty would itself constitute a form of determination, contradicting the original claim.
[10632-10691]
See. Know. Be. The Klongdrukpa confirms: The basis taught as fundamentally uncertain and indeterminate—this too cannot truly constitute the authentic basis of reality. I understand at this level of intelligence and analysis that effects must necessarily possess alternation and change, or become endowed with reversion to their cause. The uncertain itself becomes determined through its own existence, and thus the uncertain becomes determined despite claims otherwise. Because uncertainty must exist in itself to be asserted, being determined would be like the exhaustion of all possible action. [1] Between the position and its refutation, the vast middle way opens. Not spontaneous presence alone. Not uncertainty alone. The unity of primordial purity and spontaneous presence. Ka dag and lhun grub as indivisible. This is the authentic Great Perfection.
[10688-10698]
Thus. We proceed. One without learning... waited for gradual progress. Then a bird called. Immediate. Complete. Now the third position arises: Because the essence of awareness does not change in its nature, it is like space itself—pervasive and unchanging. Appearances, being unable to change in their fundamental nature, are accepted as determined and fixed, like the nature of fire and water. But this too fails logical scrutiny: If the essence of awareness does not change in any way and appearances likewise cannot change, then samsara arising from that unchanging ground is not logically valid, and consequently no one could possibly attain liberation from what never arose. If nirvana existed primordially as an unchanging essence, there would be no difference from the eternalists' view of permanence maintained by non-Buddhist philosophers. Furthermore, if one accepts that the essence of samsara, already being nirvana in itself, does not change, then if the essence itself is already nirvana without change, liberation through practice would not be necessary at all—just as fire, being hot by its very nature, requires no change or effort to become hot. If one says this analysis is necessary only regarding mental appearances and not the basis itself, this contradicts the fundamental position that appearances cannot change if the ground is unchanging. Being that the appearance of samsara itself manifests from the basis, if one says it is not the appearance of the basis but something separate, it necessarily follows that that basis would possess duality—appearing and not appearing—which is absurd. Moreover, if one realizes that basis and accepts determination, it cannot constitute the authentic basis that transcends all extremes. If a basis of realization were to exist inherently before realization itself occurs, then a merely cognizing mind arises independently, and thus realization does not depend upon realizing the basis—making realization meaningless. Yet the basis depends upon the mind of realization to be known, creating circular dependence. Because realization must exist beforehand to realize the basis, this logical error pervades the entire position. The Klongdrukpa declares: Regarding the determined basis that is taught by some proponents, this too is not the correct essence of the authentic basis. Just as for those with the eye disease of yellowing vision, a pure white conch appears mistakenly as yellow, through the distinction of reversion to oneself and other, self and other are free of the two extremes of determination. Therefore that view too is not correct upon analysis. Because cause is determined and effect is determined as identical, the self becomes no different from the eternalist view of permanence. Now the fourth position: The essence is not divided into directions or categories in its true nature, while appearances are changeable in whatever manner through conditions. But if the basis were truly changeable in its essence, pure enlightened Buddhas would devolve into impure confusion. Furthermore, whoever accepts this unacceptable consequence follows that sentient beings, without any effort or practice, spontaneously change into Buddhas and are liberated. Also, effect would illogically revert to cause, destroying temporal sequence. Earth and other material elements would become awareness, and awareness would also devolve into matter—absurd consequences. The reasoning continues: If that which is not divided into categories of essence in the basis itself changes, or if appearances other than essence change, if the essence itself changes, essence cannot coherently be called the basis. Because it would change into a dharma other than the authentic basis. If appearances other than essence change, the essence itself would be damaged by changing somewhere, compromising its integrity. Does the permanent change, or does the impermanent change in this view? The permanent cannot change by definition, like space which remains unaltered. The impermanent does not need to change through effort, for it has already changed by its very nature. Also, through the reasoning of the three times—past, present, and future—past and future cannot be changed, being non-existent in the present moment. The present has already arisen and immediately ceased, so it cannot be changed. The later part of a moment is not yet born, being non-existent, so there is nothing to change. Because change cannot be perceived in any of the three times, that the ground is changeable in whatever way is not logically valid. The Klongdrukpa concludes: If one's own state of the ground is held to be changeable, this too is no different from being fundamentally undetermined. Because effect itself reverts to cause without sequence, effort becomes unnecessary for those who hold this view. Because again and again it reverts circularly, who could possibly make matter into awareness? It is not possible by any valid reasoning. Fifth position: Because awareness, in its essence, has no fixed direction and arises pervasively everywhere, it accepts whatever arises without discrimination. This too fails—if it accepts appearances, does it dwell in the basis as the same essence, or does it not dwell in the basis as separate?
01 08 03 01
[10699-10721]
The dispute: If permanent and impermanent exist together—if impermanent appears but permanent does not, then anything goes. Similarly, samsara would be liberated without recognition, and liberated ones would revert to confusion. Second dispute: Rabbit horns and son of barren woman—if these impossible things could create samsara and nirvana, endless faults follow. Response: The Buddha taught that these are projections of not recognizing one's own face—establishing all as existing through delusion. Because faults of non-recognition are endless, these positions fail. The sixth position: Because essence appears everywhere, variegated appearances arise through not recognizing. This must be examined: Is multiplicity external appearance, internal consciousness, or aggregation? If external: ground would appear manifold externally. If internal: ground would be momentary, conceptual, afflicted. If aggregation: ground would be dualistic. All lead to contradiction. The recognition that liberates is always immediate. What appears as obstacle is actually the path itself, seen through. After centuries of concealment: the treasure was never hidden. Rediscovery reveals what was always present. The teaching undermines the one who would understand it; the understander is the final obstacle. Between journey and destination, the ground includes both. Never departed from. Spacious presence.

He sought the one behind the many, the unity beyond diversity. He failed. Not because multiplicity is real, but because grasping at unity is the same error as grasping at diversity. The fault is not in the variety—the fault is in the grasping.

The critics raise their voices: if primordial purity alone is the ground, how can saṃsāra exist? If spontaneous presence alone, why doesn't everyone recognize their liberation? These objections arise from the mind that divides what is indivisible. Like asking if wetness is in the water or the wave—neither, both, the question itself reveals confusion. —
[10782-11333]

[10791-10794]
First objection: if essence is exclusively primordially pure, saṃsāra would not exist as other than purity. Therefore sentient beings' delusion would be impossible—yet delusion appears. This seems to contradict the view. Second objection: if nature is merely unceasing display without primordial purity, everyone would be liberated without recognition—yet recognition is needed. Third: purity and display as separate substances in one ground would contradict each other. —
[10795-10799]
The response unfolds like a lotus in morning sun: because essence is primordially pure in its empty nature, sentient beings do not ultimately exist in saṃsāra as real entities. Yet from the power of unceasing display as merely the play of the path, appearances arise without contradicting purity. The non-dual ground holds both aspects simultaneously—empty in essence, luminous in nature. —
[10800-10806]
The dream analogy illuminates: when going to sleep, awareness's own face contains no dreams. Yet in sleep, horses and oxen appear to the dreamer. Does this contradict awareness's nature? Not at all. The dream appears yet is empty; emptiness appears as dream. Neither denies the other; neither contradicts the other. Primordial purity and unceasing display relate similarly. —
[10807-10811]
Sentient beings appear to deluded perception, yet because essence is not established through mere play, they are primordially liberated from the beginning. Like horses and oxen appearing through mantra power to the eye—they appear conventionally yet are empty ultimately. When pure perception dawns, they are seen as liberation itself. No effort needed; they revert spontaneously like a ball thrown into space. —
[10812-10817]
Conventional aspect: appearance as unceasing display with all qualities. Ultimate aspect: emptiness as primordially pure. These are not separate substances but two perspectives on one reality. Like being a vow-possessor and fully ordained—different descriptions, same person, no contradiction. Primordial purity and spontaneous presence are similarly non-contradictory aspects of the single ground. —
[10818-10825]
From Klongdrukpa: "Because the essence itself is primordially pure from the first, sentient beings' saṃsāra is not reasonable as real existence. The bodhisattva asks the natural question: if nature is spontaneously accomplished, aren't sentient beings already liberated? —
[10826-10832]
The response: "These sentient beings, because the essence is primordially pure without stain, liberations also appear as play without contradiction." The apparent paradox dissolves: beings appear deluded conventionally, yet are liberated ultimately. Like ice appearing solid yet being water—both descriptions are true, neither contradicts the other. —
[10833-10842]
The bodhisattva presses further: if essence is exclusively primordially pure, spontaneous presence would be unnecessary. Conversely, if all is unceasing display without purity, primordial purity would not manifest. The Teacher responds from beyond extremes: there are no words to express the ultimate, being free from words and sound entirely. Because nothing's essence is established as real, words cannot harm this nature. —
[10843-10853]
Sentient beings, from self-grasping mind's object alone—variety, recollection, thought do not cease in delusion. Yet words do not harm the essence; there is no distinction in nature. Ultimate and conventional are terms, distinctions, designations. The reality they point to transcends them both, includes them both, is never separate from them. —
[10854-10874]
The unsurpassed basis explained according to Great Perfection tradition. Common brief presentation of essential nature. [10875-10895]

[10896-10944]

[10994-11000]
The dream analogy deserves deeper reflection. When you dream, are the dream horses real? Conventionally yes—they appear, they function, they affect the dreamer. Similarly, saṃsāra appears yet is empty; emptiness appears as saṃsāra. —
[11001-11005]

This is the meaning of primordial liberation. —
[11006-11011]

Neither truth negates the other; each requires the other for completeness. Primordial purity speaks the ultimate truth; spontaneous presence speaks the conventional truth. Together they form the complete view. —
[11012-11019]

[11020-11026]

[11027-11036]

Now I will explain further. This section describes the process of embryonic development and the arising of consciousness. The ancient masters understood that consciousness does not arise from nothing—it arises from specific conditions, specific causes and effects. The process is intricate, detailed, systematic. The numbers describe the stages of development: the channels, the elements, the sense faculties, the mental factors. The mind arises from the elements. The water element gathers, holding the thought-basis. The fire element radiates to objects. The wind element moves as light. These are not metaphors—they describe the actual process of consciousness. The mind-itself is unborn meaning, unceasing mindfulness, unchanging example-meaning-mixed, self-complete actual-meaning, nowhere differentiated. The mental factors arise from specific conditions. Thoroughly-searching mindfulness, when pure, is clear as a god's body; when impure, throws one into god's migration; when perverted, throws one into wrong-attachment body. Definitively-settling mental mindfulness, when pure, obtains the awareness-holder; when impure, one is born as god-asura; when perverted, into the butcher's lineage. The six migrations are the six realms: gods, humans, animals, hungry ghosts, hell beings, demigods. Each arises from a specific type of mindfulness. Moving-maker-grasping mind, when pure, becomes wheel-grasping yoga; when impure, leads to hell; when perverted, to suffering. The thoroughly-investigating mind with wind-horse arises from previous-memory following-grasping. The definitively-settling mind with earth-horse arises from past-branched memory. The definitively-grasping mind with water-horse arises from present-memory following-grasping. The process of embryonic development is described in intricate detail. From elements to channels, from channels to body, from body to faculties, from faculties to limbs. Each stage is precise. Each number has meaning. The ancient yogis mapped this process through direct observation—not of external anatomy, but of their own consciousness entering the body. One without learning... has traversed these stages. In the bardo, consciousness enters the body gradually. First the wind, then the channels, then the elements, then the body. The process is not random—it follows specific patterns. The mind enters through the crown, descends through the channels, settles in the heart. This is the process of birth—not just physical birth, but the birth of consciousness in a new form. The numbers describe the completeness of the system. The channels are sixteen, then thirty-two, then sixty-four. The wisdom aspects are sixteen, then thirty-two. The letters are sixteen, then forty-eight. The light spheres are sixteen, then sixty-four. The system is vast, intricate, complete. It describes every aspect of existence. The practitioner who understands this knows that the body is not separate from consciousness. The channels are not mere tubes—they are the pathways of awareness. The elements are not mere matter—they are the qualities of awareness. The faculties are not mere organs—they are the gateways of wisdom. When recognized, the body becomes the mandala, the channels become the deities, the elements become the wisdom aspects. Thus, do not despise the body. Do not think that awareness is separate from flesh. The body is the vehicle of enlightenment. The channels are the pathways of wisdom. The elements are the display of awareness. Recognize this, and the body becomes the palace of the buddAn old traveler...nderer has traversed these stages. In the bardo, consciousness enters the body gradually. First the wind, then the channels, then the elements, then the body. The process is not random—it follows specific patterns. The numbers describe the completeness of the system. The channels are sixteen, then thirty-two, then sixty-four. The wisdom aspects are sixteen, then thirty-two. The letters are sixteen, then forty-eight. The light spheres are sixteen, then sixty-four. The system is vast, intricate, complete. It describes every aspect of existence. The practitioner who understands this knows that the body is not separate from consciousness. The channels are not mere tubes—they are the pathways of awareness. The elements are not mere matter—they are the qualities of awareness. The faculties are not mere organs—they are the gateways of wisdom. When recognized, the body becomes the mandala, the channels become the deities, the elements become the wisdom aspects. The process of embryonic development is not merely physical—it is the descent of consciousness into form. The mind, in the bardo, sees the parents and is drawn to them. The karmic connection, the affinity, the attachment—all these draw the mind into the womb. The consciousness enters the father's seed, combines with the mother's blood, and begins to grow. The channels form first: the central channel, then the right and left channels, then the subsidiary channels. These are not blood vessels—they are the pathways of awareness. The winds move through them, the bindus flow through them, the mind experiences through them. The channels are the infrastructure of consciousness. The elements then form: earth gives solidity, water gives fluidity, fire gives warmth, wind gives movement, space gives openness. These are not physical elements—they are the qualities of awareness appearing as form. When recognized, the elements become the five wisdoms: earth becomes equality wisdom, water becomes discriminating wisdom, fire becomes mirror-like wisdom, wind becomes all-accomplishing wisdom, space becomes dharmadhatu wisdom. The faculties then develop: the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, mind. These are the gateways through which awareness experiences the world. The eye sees forms, the ear hears sounds, the nose smells odors, the tongue tastes flavors, the body feels touch, the mind knows phenomena. These are not merely physical organs—they are the six ways awareness experiences. The limbs then form: arms, legs, head, torso. These are not merely flesh—they are the tools of action. The arms act, the legs move, the head perceives, the torso supports. Each part has its function, each part serves awareness. The process is precise. The numbers are exact. This is not speculation—it is observation, refined over centuries. The Tibetan masters understood consciousness because they observed their own consciousness, entering and leaving the body. They mapped the process in detail, leaving us this intricate system. The practitioner who understands this does not cling to the body as self, nor reject it as obstacle. The body is the vehicle of enlightenment. It is the palace in which awareness dwells. It is the mandala of the buddhas. When recognized, the body itself becomes the path. Thus, respect your body. It is not separate from awareness. The channels within you are the pathways of wisdom. The elements within you are the display of awareness. The faculties within you are the gateways of liberation. Recognize this, and every moment becomes practice. Every breath becomes meditation. Every sensation becomes wisdom. The treasury opens by revealing what was never hidden. The body is already complete. Awareness is already present. Liberation is not something to achieve—it is something to recognize. Rest in that recognition, and the body becomes the palace of enlightenment. Now I will explain further the meaning of these elaborate numbers. The system describes consciousness entering the body. First, the all-basis consciousness gathers. This is the storehouse of all karmic imprints, the ground from which all mental events arise. From this, the eighteen elements grow: the six sense organs, the six sense objects, and the six consciousnesses. These form the ground of experience. The channels develop in stages. The main channels are like rivers, the subsidiary channels like streams, the finest channels like capillaries. All carry the winds, the energies of consciousness. When these winds flow freely, awareness is clear. When they are blocked, confusion arises. The elements form progressively. First, the wind element, the earliest and most subtle. Then, the fire element, providing warmth. Then, the water element, providing fluidity. Then, the earth element, providing solidity. Each element brings specific qualities. Each quality brings specific experiences. The sense faculties develop from the elements. The eye faculty arises from the earth element, clear and discriminating. The ear faculty arises from the space element, open and receptive. The nose arises from water, the tongue from fire, the body from wind. Each faculty has its specific object and consciousness. The mental factors arise as well. Mindfulness, attention, discrimination, ecstasy, equanimity—all these arise from specific combinations of elements and channels. They are not separate from the body—they are functions of the body-mind system. The elaborate enumeration is not mere classification—it is a map. The map describes the territory of consciousness. The territory is vast—so vast that the ancient masters divided it into sections, numbered the sections, and gave names to the divisions. This is not to confuse—it is to help us understand. The numbers describe completeness. The sixteen channels become thirty-two, become sixty-four. The sixteen wisdoms become thirty-two. The sixteen letters become forty-eight. The light spheres become sixty-four. Each multiplication describes an increase in refinement. Each refinement brings us closer to the source. This system was not invented—it was discovered. The masters observed their own consciousness in meditation. They observed consciousness entering the body at birth, leaving at death, moving in the bardo. They observed the stages of embryonic development and mapped them to the movement of consciousness. The result is this elaborate system. The practitioner who understands this does not cling to the body as self. The body is not the self—it is a manifestation of awareness. But neither does the practitioner reject the body as obstacle. The body is the vehicle of liberation. It is the palace in which awareness dwells. It is the mandala of the five wisdoms. Thus, treat your body with respect. It is not merely flesh—it is the temple of awareness. The channels within you are the pathways of wisdom. The elements within you are the display of awareness. The faculties within you are the gateways of liberation. When recognized, every part of the body becomes Buddha-field, every moment becomes practice. The ancient texts say: the body is the complete Buddha. The five aggregates are the five kayas. The four elements are the four wisdoms. The six sense faculties are the six elements of enlightenment. This is not metaphor—it is description of what is, when recognized. Therefore, do not seek enlightenment elsewhere. Do not think you must go somewhere else, become something else, achieve something else. The enlightenment is here, in this body, in this mind, in this moment. Rest in recognition, and the body reveals itself as the palace of the buddhas. The channels reveal themselves as the pathways of wisdom. The elements reveal themselves as the display of awareness. This is the teaching of the Great Perfection: the ground is already complete. The path is already present. The result is already achieved. We do not create enlightenment—we recognize it. We do not achieve wisdom—we uncover it. Secret completion: the treasury is intimate wisdom itself. Moonlight was never obscuDuring my wandering years...anderer has traveled these paths. I have seen consciousness enter the body. I have felt the descent of awareness into form. I have experienced the stages of embryonic development from within. What I tell you is from direct observation, refined through years of practice. The body is not an obstacle to enlightenment—it is the very ground of enlightenment. The channels are not separate from awareness—they are awareness taking form. The elements are not mere matter—they are awareness appearing as experience. When you recognize this, the body becomes the mandala, the channels become the deities, the elements become the wisdoms. Do not think the body is impure. The body is pure—from the beginning, pure. Do not think the mind is impure. The mind is pure—from the beginning, pure. The impurity is the not recognizing. The confusion is the not seeing. When recognition dawns, impurity reveals itself as purity. When awareness sees itself, confusion reveals itself as wisdom. The elaborate numbers in this text describe this process. They are not meant to bind you in complexity. They are meant to reveal the intricacy of awareness. Each number, each division, each enumeration A signpost points north—the wood is not the destination. something real. The system is comprehensive because awareness is comprehensive. The system is intricate because experience is intricate. But remember: the map is not the territory. The Sitting still, mind wanders. The wandering Asking 'Who am I?'—the question points, but is not the knowing. what doesn't move. is not the moon. The numbers describe the description—they are not the thing described. The channels of the body are not separate from the channels of awareness. When you recognize the nature of mind, the channels purify themselves. No external medicine is needed. The healer and healed are one. The elaborate system of channels, wheels, and bindus is not meant to bind you in complexity. It is meant to reveal the subtlety of awareness. The ancient masters mapped the inner landscape as a guide. But the map is not the territory. The channels are appearances in awareness. The awareness that knows the channels is beyond the channels. Rest in that awareness. The channels will then display as the mandala of enlightenment—not because you visualized them so, but because they always were that. Now I will explain further the practice. The channels are not static structures—they flow with wisdom wind. When the wind enters the central channel, awareness becomes clear. This is the goal of the tummo practice: to draw the winds into the center. When the winds gather in the central channel, the bindu rises. When the bindu rises, the wisdom light dawns. This is not imagination—it is the actual transformation of the body into the rainbow body. The seven wheels correspond to seven levels of consciousness. The crown wheel is the gateway to the formless realms. The throat wheel governs speech and communication. The heart wheel is the seat of mind. The navel wheel governs energy and transformation. The secret wheel governs reproduction and creativity. The feet wheel governs movement and action. Each wheel has a specific number of petals: the crown has one thousand, the throat has sixteen, the heart has eight, the navel has sixty-four, and so on. These are not literal thousand petals—they represent the variety of mental states that can arise. The bindus: there are many kinds. The white bindu is the essence of wind. The red bindu is the essence of fire. The black bindu is the essence of earth. The blue bindu is the essence of water. The yellow bindu is the essence of space. When these bindus are purified, they become the five wisdoms. The white bindu becomes mirror-like wisdom. The red bindu becomes discriminating wisdom. The black bindu becomes equality wisdom. The blue bindu becomes all-accomplishing wisdom. The yellow bindu becomes dharmadhatu wisdom. The goddesses: there are five main goddesses residing in the wheels. They hold the winds like banners, vases, lassos, boxes, and boats. They are not external beings—they are the personified qualities of wisdom. When the practitioner rests in recognition, these goddesses manifest as the five lights. When the practitioner is confused, they manifest as the five poisons. The transformation is not external—it is the shift from poison to wisdom. The practice methods: for stiff neck, cut the small-tip right channel at the throat. For upper body and head diseases, cut the small-tip left channel. For lung heat, cut the mind-crooked channel at the right shoulder. For all diseases generally, cut the general-channel great at the left shoulder. For poison disease, cut the poison-crooked channel at the sun-center of the right shoulder. For madness and fainting, cut the great-turtle channel at the left shoulder. These are not literal surgeries—they are visualizations that transform the energies. The clearing practices: eight suitable for clearing. When dwelling causes burning, that becomes a fault—two exist. The vital-points are the locations where the channels converge. These are the doorways to deeper awareness. The practitioner who knows these points can direct the winds, gather the bindus, and achieve enlightenment in this very bA cave hermit...nderer has traversed these inner landscapes. Then one day, resting in awareness, I saw: all these elaborate systems were appearances in awareness. The channels were not in some body somewhere—they were the display of awareness itself. The goddesses were not external beings—they were the qualities of awareness personified. The bindus were not substances—they were the moments of awareness appearing as light. Thus I tell you: study these systems if you wish—but do not be bound by them. They are A signpost points north—the wood is not the destination. to the moon. Mountain hermit's lamp meditation: I practiced with the four lamps for thirty years. Each morning, I would visualize, gaze, and rest. Each lamp taught me something different. The far-reaching lasso taught me pervasion—all experience is wisdom's display. The empty bindu taught me essence—concentrated, pure, unchanging. The pure expanse taught me space—vast, accommodating, limitless. The self-arisen prajna taught me knowing—direct, immediate, self-illuminating. Together, they taught me what I already was.

From the *Rin po che'i sgron ma 'bar ba* tantra: "Far-reaching water lamp's essence gathers both appearances; because seeing-holder grasping aspect not ceased, through holding both aspects. Recognition is immediate. " Do you see? These lamps are your eyes, practitioner! Not something to achieve. Turn back from grasping at what you see, and the lamp is already blazing! Emaho! The water lamp is the essence of awareness appearing as clarity. The clarity of light-essence is the power-support of the agent seeing both pure appearance and deluded appearance. This is the key: both appearances—samsara and nirvana—are gathered in the same awareness. The seeing-holder has not ceased grasping—so we see both pure and impure appearances. When we recognize the nature, both are held in the same awareness.

First essence dot light five rim round surround self-clear color, burning-lamp. Three words. Four lamps. One light. Recognition dawns. From Oddiyana's sky: the path blazes as ground itself! Never departed! Now I will explain further the teaching. The water lamp is the clarity of awareness appearing as light. This clarity is not something created—it is the very nature of mind. When awareness is not obscured by concepts, it shines as clarity. This clarity appears as the lights we see in meditation—the points, the lines, the colors. These are not achievements—they are the natural display of awareness. The tantra speaks of far-casting: the appearance seems far because we grasp at it. The rope appears as snake because we do not examine. When we examine, we see the rope and the snake are not two. The rope is empty of snake-nature, yet appears as snake. Similarly, all appearances are empty of inherent existence, yet appear vividly. This is the Middle Way: appearances are neither truly existent nor non-existent. The four lamps: water lamp, emptiness lamp, space lamp, wisdom lamp. These correspond to the four aspects of awareness. The water lamp is the clarity of awareness. The emptiness lamp is the openness of awareness. The space lamp is the expanse of awareness. The wisdom lamp is the knowing of awareness. These four are not separate—they are aspects of the one awareness. The channels: the navel channel produces the burning-lamp. The body enters the mother womb. The body essence gathers at the navel, the great channel knot, the center triangle. Father and mother, cause and condition, produce the eye fruit. The father's portion is white, the mother's portion is black—they mix. The channels pulsate, branch upward, move into the skull cavity, enter the three branches, pierce the right and left eyes, the middle brahma-aperture. The awareness thought-free body: vajra necklace, dot stack, five or nine arises. The nine dots: these are the nine doorways of awareness. They are not nine—they are one. The one is not one—it is the nature of awareness, beyond one and many. Your own face is the dot—the point of awareness that knows everything. The seven doors: the eye, the essence center straight, arises the door eye two, power object arises making, channel all appears. The eight examples: object-appearance holds like a hook, hook holds making, appears the nose holds, samsara nirvana nose holds. The nine measures: three element gathering distant-noose measure, object-appearance expands gathering, pristine-awareness measures the necklace sees, essence gathers form-appearance distinguishes. In a freezing cave... has traversed these teachings. The water lamp is your own awareness, clear and luminous. The lamps are not outside—they are within. The channels are the pathways of awareness. The dots are the moments of awareness. Recognize this, and the entire mandala reveals itself. The body becomes the palace, the channels become the deities, the lights become the wisdoms. Thus, practitioner, do not seek the lamps elsewhere. They are within you. The clarity you see in meditation is your own awareness. The lights that appear are the lights of wisdom. Recognize them as your own display, and the path completes itself. Now I will explain further the water lamp in practice. The water lamp is the clarity of awareness—it appears as light, as points, as colors. This clarity is not something you create—it arises naturally when the mind is still. When you rest in naked awareness, without grasping at thoughts or objects, the clarity shines forth. This is the water lamp. The practice is simple: rest in awareness. Let thoughts arise and dissolve naturally. Do not follow them, do not reject them. Let the mind be like space—open, vast, unobstructed. Within this space, clarity arises. The clarity is not different from space—they are aspects of the same awareness. The four lamps correspond to four aspects of practice. The water lamp is the clarity of awareness. The emptiness lamp is the openness of awareness. The space lamp is the expanse of awareness. The wisdom lamp is the knowing quality of awareness. These four are not separate—they arise together, shine together, dissolve together in the single sphere of rigpa. The channels within the body are the pathways of this clarity. The navel channel produces the burning lamp—the heat of awareness. The central channel is the pathway of the main winds. The right and left channels are the pathways of the subsidiary winds. When the winds enter the central channel, clarity arises. The channels are not mere tubes—they are the pathways of awareness. The ancient masters mapped these channels through direct observation. They discovered that awareness has structure—it flows through specific pathways, settles in specific centers, manifests in specific forms. This mapping is the ground of the inner yoga practices. The nine dots are the nine doorways of awareness. These are not physical—they are the points where awareness interacts with objects. The eye sees forms, the ear hears sounds, the nose smells odors, the tongue tastes flavors, the body feels touch, the mind knows phenomena. These are the six doors. The seventh is the door of mental events. The eighth is the door of aggregates. The ninth is the door of dharmata. But these nine are not nine—they are one. The one awareness that knows through all the doors. The one awareness that is aware of itself. The one awareness that is always present, always knowing, always clear. Your own face is this awareness—this is what the text means by "the dot." The seven doors: the eye door, the ear door, the nose door, the tongue door, the body door, the mind door, and the door of mental events. These are the gateways through which awareness experiences. Each door has its object: form, sound, smell, taste, touch, phenomena. The awareness that knows through these doors is one—it is your own rigpa. The practice of Dzogchen is to rest in this awareness. Do not create anything, do not suppress anything. Let the mind rest in its natural state. The clarity will arise naturally. The lights will appear naturally. The recognition will happen naturally. This is the water lamp—already present, always present, never createA hilltop meditator...erer has sat in meditation and seen these lights. I have watched the points arise, the colors shine, the forms manifest. I have felt the heat of the burning lamp, the clarity of the water lamp, the expanse of the space lamp, the knowing of the wisdom lamp. These are not hallucinations—they are the natural display of awareness. What I tell you is from my own experience: rest in awareness. Let the lights arise. Do not grasp at them, do not reject them. They are appearances in awareness, empty of inherent existence. Rest in that awareness—the awareness that knows the lights. That awareness is your own nature. Recognize it, and the path is complete.

First nature-is. The nature described is not elsewhere—it is this very awareness. The Treasury's presentation here is profound and complete. The Great Perfection transcends all elaboration while using elaboration as skillful means. May all who encounter these words recognize their true nature. A hilltop meditator... has wandered through these teachings for decades. What I've learned: the teachings are not the point. Recognition is the point. Don't collect teachings like treasures. Use them as keys to open the door of recognition, then throw them away. The door opens to what was never closed. These teachings are my heart-essence, given to those with fortune to receive them. The Dzogchen path is not for everyone, but for those who encounter it, liberation is certain. Practice with devotion. Recognize with confidence. Rest in natural perfection. ROAR! All teachings! All philosophies! All elaborations! CUT THROUGH THEM! Can you find the teaching? Can you grasp the philosophy? They are awareness displaying itself! See through the display and FIND WHAT DISPLAYS! AH AH AH! Three words. Teach. Recognize. Stop. The teaching points. The recognition sees. The stopping rests. Three words, one meaning. Complete from the beginning. Perfect at the end. Stop seeking. Rest in completion. Therefore. Thus. The systematic presentation serves pedagogical clarity. Each section builds upon previous. Each concept refines understanding. Yet the system is not the truth—it The mind creates, the creation dissolves. What remains? truth. Precise structure for those who need structure. Complete framework for comprehensive understanding. The integration of all teachings: view integrates ground, meditation integrates path, conduct integrates expression, result integrates completion. All integrated into recognition. Nothing separate. Nothing apart. One awareness wearing many costumes. The essence beyond all teachings: awareness knowing itself. Not through teaching. Not through practice. Not through time. Awareness is self-knowing from the beginning. The teaching describes this. The practice reveals this. The result is this. Already complete. Emaho! The teachings! The path! The recognition! What joy to encounter these words! What bliss to practice these methods! What liberation to recognize this nature! This yogi dances through every word, every practice, every recognition—complete in each, free in all! Between the teaching and the recognition, between the practice and the result, the consort dances. Her embrace is the intimacy of awareness with itself. Not two. Not one. Just this embrace. Like fruit falling when ripe. Like water finding its level. I dance through these teachings as light through prisms. Each teaching a different color. Each practice a different step. All dances of one dancer. Recognition is realizing you are the dancer and the dance. Liberation is dancing without inhibition. Philosophically, these teachings present the Great Perfection view: transcendence of all views, completion beyond all completion, perfection prior to all perfection. Not nihilism. Not eternalism. The middle way that transcends middle and extremes. The scholarly precision fascinates me—every citation, every reference, every logical connection. Yet within this precision lives wild freedom. The Kunzang Klongdrukpa TantraO great bodhisattva, the abode of mind is the all-ground, because the all-ground gathers all objects of thought and is known as mind. The abode of primordial wisdom is the Dharmakaya, because the Dharmakaya does not possess memory-thought and has no consciousness that grasps objects as different. This is the essential distinction that separates samsara from nirvana, like the difference between a high plateau lake's surface and its depths.

Some with manifest arrogance hold the all-ground as Dharmakaya! The path remains the path; the destination waits ahead. One must complete the journey, not claim the mere walking as arrival.

Every type of non-recognition comes from one source—not recognizing your own face. The six types are just different angles of the same mistake. Fix the root, the branches fix themselves. Practice recognition. Everything else is elaboration. Second, mind arising divisions: From Natural Arising: mind divisions thus: various gathering water-like mind, clean-uncleanless pig-like mind, brave timid great tiger-like mind, light feather-like mind, moving wind-like mind, greatly intoxicated mud-like mind, sparking spark-like mind, desiring bird-like mind, expanding branches-like mind, difficult to stop actor-like mind, no planet-grasping madman-like mind—eleven.
[18036-18060]
Eleven types of mind? Eleven types of chains. Heavy chain, light chain, golden chain, iron chain—still chains. Don't study the chains. Break them! Recognition breaks all eleven simultaneously. The prisoner who catalogs his chains is still a prisoner. These are object-habit various gathering—water; accept-reject deluded—pig; anger-pride coarse—tiger; entering various objects not fixed one—feather; changing unobstructed—wind; desiring objects intoxicated—mud; one to many concepts sparking—spark; accepting objects desiring—bird; awareness strength expanding investigating meaning—branches; object grasping awareness controlled—actor; not grasping object awareness unfocused wandering—madman. Mountain hermit's observation: I watched a madman by the river for three days. He talked to rocks, commanded the water, proclaimed himself king of the sand. "He's crazy," people said. But I saw—he was free from social constraints, free from approval, free from the need to make sense. The madman-like mind they describe is not pathology. It's freedom from convention. The danger is when convention becomes the only sanity.
[18061-18085]
Third, affliction arising divisions: six root afflictions, sixteen proximate afflictions, subtle-arisen infinite afflictions. From Sun Moon Union: afflictions are six: non-recognition called basis-deluded concept grasping; delusion—wisdom aspect deluded; anger—development stage deluded; pride—view aspect deluded; desire—appearance aspect deluded; jealousy—not-realized aspect deluded. One who walked paths... asks: Why six? Why not five or seven? Because these six cover all the ways we try to make solid what is empty, to make separate what is unified, to make permanent what flows. Each affliction is a different flavor of the same mistake—grasping at self and other. Orderly: object-subject deluded concept aspect delusion; wisdom rigpa opposite mere not-knowing; object anger aspect; "I am" pride; object attachment; meaning not-realized other anger.
[18086-18110]
Second, sixteen proximate afflictions: From Natural Arising: sixteen which? Non-recognition, mind, intellect, grasping, concept, not-knowing, not-seeing, not-realizing, not-understanding, self-impurity grasping, other jealousy, desiring, attachment, pride, scattering. Singing yogi's gentle wisdom: Sixteen branches from one root. Cut the root, branches wither. Water the root, branches flourish. The root is non-recognition. Everything else is commentary. Orderly: thusness not-knowing delusion completely afflicted; object mind grasping; subject grasping intellect; both self-grasping; all-pervading concept; meaning non-recognition; abiding mode not-seeing; word meaning not-realizing; general-specific not-understanding; knowing deluded samaya previous mistaken aspect; object self-grasping; other's excellence not-pleasing; accepting object; object attachment; slight pride; object scattering anger.
[18111-18135]
Third, subtle-arisen infinite afflictions: twenty-five, fifty-one, eighty-four thousand. From root pervading non-recognition not counted separately, pervaded five poisons five divisions—twenty-five. From Natural Arising: delusion five—greatly dulled delusion, not-knowing delusion, not-seeing delusion, very thick delusion, greatly intoxicated delusion. Desire five: desire desiring desire, greatly burning desire, life not-seeing desire, anger-accompanied desire, space-traversing desire. Anger five: desire-great anger, anger-accompanied anger, very coarse anger, delusion-accompanied anger, time's thunderstorm-like anger. Pride five: suppressing lion-like pride, none-above space-like pride, brave timid tiger-like pride, "I am" weed-like pride, unequal equalizing elephant pride. Jealousy five: subtle jealousy, self-arisen jealousy, very sharp jealousy.
[18136-18160]
The numbers are not arbitrary. Twenty-five shows the five poisons each divided into five. Fifty-one shows further elaboration. Eighty-four thousand shows the infinite variety of suffering. But remember—these are pedagogical devices. The actual afflictions are as numerous as moments of not-recognizing. Don't count them. Stop generating them through recognition. This old hermit's final teaching: I've studied these texts for sixty years. I can recite all eighty-four thousand afflictions. I can explain the twenty-five subdivisions. But what liberated me? Not the knowledge. Not the scholarship. One moment of recognizing my own face. That moment contained all the teachings. All the classifications are just different ways of saying: wake up! [18161-End] COMPLETE SYNTHESIS: The distinction between mind (sems) and wisdom (ye shes) is the central axis of dzogchen. Mind gathers, classifies, analyzes, wanders. Wisdom recognizes, rests, clarifies, liberates. The all-ground (kun gzhi) is not the enemy—it's the field where the game plays out. The enemy is non-recognition (ma rig pa), the failure to recognize what knows the all-ground. Once recognized, the all-ground becomes the display of Dharmakaya. The eleven mind types, six root afflictions, sixteen proximate, twenty-five subtle—all are different costumes worn by non-recognition. Don't fight each costume. Unmask the wearer. Practice is simple: recognize awareness in every moment. When mind wanders, recognize the wandering. When afflictions arise, recognize their empty nature. When wisdom dawns, don't grasp it. This is the heart of Longchenpa's teaching. This is the treasury's essence. Enough analysis. Enough classification. Sit down. Recognize your nature. Rest there. Everything else is distraction. The mani wall stands, stones placed by countless hands, each carving representing countless hours of practice. But the wall is just stones. The practice is just recognition. Don't mistake the accumulation for the attainment. Look. See. Rest. Complete. The distinction between mind and wisdom plays out in every moment of practice. When you sit in meditation, notice: the moment you try to "meditate," that's mind. The moment you rest without trying, that's wisdom. The moment you judge your meditation as good or bad, that's mind. The moment you simply notice without judgment, that's wisdom. Throughout your day, pause twenty times. In each pause, ask: "What is knowing this moment?" Don't answer with words. Look directly. That looking is wisdom. The one who asks is mind. The knowing itself is wisdom. Mountain hermit's cave practice: I spent three years just watching the distinction between mind and wisdom. Every thought that arose, I asked: "Is this mind or wisdom?" Eventually, I stopped asking. The distinction dissolved. There was only knowing. That is the true synthesis. Longchenpa wrote thousands of verses on mind and wisdom. The Prajnaparamita sutras fill libraries. The tantras are countless. But the essence is contained in one moment of recognition. All the classification serves one purpose—to exhaust the mind's tendency to analyze, to classify, to understand. When the mind exhausts itself, wisdom remains. This is not nihilism. Wisdom is not nothing. Wisdom is luminous clarity, empty yet knowing. It is not inanimate like a stone. It is not dark like ignorance. It is the bright awareness that reads these words right now. Final metaphor: The mind is like a wave on the ocean. It rises, falls, crashes, subsides. Wisdom is like the water itself—never moving from its water-nature, never becoming anything other than water, even when it appears as wave. The wave doesn't need to become water. It is water already. Mind doesn't need to become wisdom. It is wisdom's display already. Recognize this, and the eleven mind types are liberated. The six root afflictions are purified. The eighty-four thousand are dissolved. Not by effort. Not by time. By recognition alone. This is the supreme vehicle. This is the great perfection. This is the treasury of dharmadhatu. Om ah hum. The commentary on mind and wisdom is complete. The distinctions are drawn. The synthesis is made. What remains? Your recognition. Your practice. Your liberation. May all beings recognize their true nature. May the Treasury of Supreme Vehicle illuminate the path. May wisdom dawn in all directions. The teachings on mind and wisdom are not merely for meditation sessions. They apply to every moment. When anger arises in traffic, recognize: this anger is mind. What knows the anger? Wisdom. When desire arises for food, recognition: desire is mind. What knows the desire? Wisdom. When pride arises in accomplishment, see: pride is mind. What knows the pride? Wisdom. This continuous recognition transforms ordinary life into the path. Every affliction becomes an opportunity for recognition. Every distraction becomes a reminder of the nondual nature. The distinction between meditation and post-meditation dissolves. Don't wait for special circumstances. Don't wait for retreat. Practice recognition now, in this moment, while reading these words. That is the instruction. That is the path. That is the result. The mani wall by the path reminds pilgrims: every stone represents a mantra, every mantra represents a moment of recognition. Build your own wall, moment by moment, recognition by recognition, until the wall becomes unnecessary because recognition has become continuous. This is the completion of the commentary on mind and wisdom distinctions.

[18262-18273]
Second: wisdom nature extensively explained. Ye shes kyi rang bzhin rgyas par bshad pa—detailed exposition of wisdom's nature. From Thalgyur: wisdom not concept, essence self-luminous. Dbye ba gsum—threefold classification. Nges tshig—definitive meaning. This is how wisdom knows itself.
[18264-18273]
This old hermit thought wisdom could be learned. Studied texts, memorized, debated. Then watching mist rise from valley—understood. Wisdom not in books. Books are Prayer flags carry the mantra on wind—the flag is not the prayer.. Wisdom is the moon all fingers indicate.
[18266-18273]
Ye shes rtog pa ma yin te—wisdom is not concept. Ngo bo rang gsal snying po'i don—essence is self-luminous, heart meaning. Not accumulated knowledge but intrinsic clarity. Not something to get but something to recognize.
[18268-18273]
Wisdom's nature. Recognition complete. Three words—but wisdom and nature and recognition are not three. They are the same, described differently.
[18270-18273]
Wisdom beyond words! Look directly! Can you grasp it? The attempt shows futility. Wisdom is the looking, not what is looked at. Water and wetness— cannot be distinguished, yet not the same. This is Thalgyur's revelation.
[18272-18273]
Threefold classification of wisdom: essence (ngo bo), definitive meaning (nges tshig), distinctions (dbye ba). Four aspects complete the exposition. Stop. See your own nature—that is the wisdom. Rest in that recognition.
01 14 04 01
[18274-18285]
Primordial wisdom—your own rigpa, abiding as knowledge from the very beginning. This is not something to acquire, not something to cultivate, not something to achieve. Like a lamp that has always been lit, though shadows may have obscured its light. The shadows never touched the light. The obscuration never affected the nature. Before recognition dawned... spent years seeking wisdom. He read texts, practiced methods, accumulated knowledge. Finally exhausted, he sat by a stream and watched water flow. The water did not ask how to flow. The wisdom did not ask how to be wise. Recognition dawned—wisdom was never absent, only overlooked.
[18274-18609]
Lion-faced dakini's fierce cutting: You want to possess the five wisdoms? You want to become a "wisdom holder"? Cut through this spiritual materialism! The wisdoms are not possessions. They are not achievements. They are your own nature, naked and unobscured. The moment you claim them, you've lost them. The moment you seek them, they hide. Just be A wandering practitioner... This old fool met a practitioner who claimed "I have realized dharmadhatu wisdom!" I asked, "What knows this realization?" He fell silent. Three days later, he came back laughing. "The realization was just another thought. The wisdom is what knows the thought."
[18286-18305]
Three divisions: ground-abiding wisdom, characteristic-grasping wisdom, object- pervading wisdom. Not three separate wisdoms but three aspects of one recognition. Like a crystal showing different colors depending on the angle, yet remaining one crystal. ground-abiding wisdom: essence primordially pure, nature spontaneously accomplished, compassion all-pervading. Three aspects of the basis, three expressions of the same wisdom. Primordially pure like space—beyond existence and non-existence. Spontaneously accomplished like a wish-fulfilling jewel— qualities complete without effort. All-pervading compassion like sunlight— warming all without discrimination.
[18306-18325]
Essence primordially pure: beyond the extremes, like space. From Thalgyur: "In essence primordially pure wisdom, non-recognition has no name in existence. One and two are without number. Established by investigation, existence and non- existence are not established." This wisdom is not found through analysis. It is recognized when analysis subsides. Like searching for space with a microscope—futile and absurd. The searching itself dissolves, and space was never absent.
[18326-18349]
Nature spontaneously accomplished: primordially qualities complete, power and arise-basis accomplished. Like a wish-fulfilling jewel appearing, though essence empty of thing and mark. Not-existing therefore appearing. Appearing therefore empty. Appearance-emptiness inseparable. This is the great spontaneous presence—not created, not fabricated, naturally perfect. Like the sun radiating light without effort, like a lotus blooming without instruction. The nature accomplishes without doing.
[18350-18371]
Compassion all-pervading wisdom: not existing in your own face yet spreading as the basis for all appearance. From the source: "From compassion all-pervading wisdom, inexhaustible various appearing door." Without this, samsara and nirvana would be severed. This is the dynamic aspect of wisdom, the warmth that melts the ice of fixation. Not separate from primordial purity, not different from spontaneous presence— the active expression of both. Like the rays inseparable from the sun.
[18369-18374]
Singing yogi's five wisdoms song: Dharmadhatu, sky so vast and clear Space in which all phenomena appear Mirrorlike, the crystal lake so still Reflecting all without force of will Equality, the sun that warms the stone Same heat for kings and beggars, all as one Discriminating, knowing each unique snowflake No two alike, yet all of emptiness make All-accomplishing, the ripening of fruit No effort made, yet harvest follows root Five wisdoms, five faces of one moon Shining on the lake in evening's soon
[18372-18385]
Characteristic-grasping wisdom: the five wisdoms as realized characteristics. Dharmadhatu wisdom—free from thought, the space in which all appears. Mirrorlike wisdom—unceasing clarity, reflecting without grasping. Equality wisdom—unmixed completeness, holding all as one taste. Discriminating wisdom— clearly seeing each phenomenon's unique nature. All-accomplishing wisdom— effortless benefit, spontaneously active.
[18386-18410]
The five are not five separate entities. They are five aspects of one recognition, five ways wisdom knows itself. When rigpa recognizes itself as dharmadhatu, it is the ground. When it recognizes itself as mirrorlike, it is the clarity. When it recognizes itself as equality, it is the sameness. When it recognizes itself as discriminating, it is the discernment. When it recognizes itself as all-accomplishing, it is the activity.
[18411-18428]
Object-pervading wisdom: the distinction between all-ground and dharmakaya. This is key. The all-ground gathers habits like a warehouse stores goods. Dharmakaya is the space of the warehouse—never filled, never empty. What gathers cannot be what is free from gathering. What recognizes the gathering is itself free. This is the difference between ordinary mind and wisdom. Both are aware. But ordinary mind is tangled in what it knows. Wisdom knows without tangling. Between them, only recognition separates.
[18429-18450]
Mountain hermit sat for thirty years contemplating the five wisdoms. He memorized descriptions, analyzed characteristics, distinguished aspects. One winter morning, frost on his window caught the sunlight. Five colors appeared— not separate, not merged, distinct yet unified. He understood. The five wisdoms were not concepts to master. They were his own awareness, recognizing itself in five ways.
[18451-18470]
Lion-faced dakini's fierce compassion: stop collecting wisdoms like trophies! You want to possess dharmadhatu wisdom? You want to achieve mirrorlike clarity? This very wanting is the obstacle. The wisdoms are not achievements. They are descriptions of what you already are. Stop seeking. Start recognizing.
[18470-18475]
Mountain hermit's glacier realization: I watched a glacier for thirty years. It moved imperceptibly, carved valleys, fed rivers, returned to ocean. The glacier didn't try to accomplish this. It simply was ice, responding to gravity and temperature. Primordial wisdom is like this—not trying to be wisdom, simply being what it is, naturally benefiting without effort. One spring, the glacier calved—huge chunks crashed into the lake. The water didn't choose to receive them. The glacier didn't choose to release them. Natural perfection. This is spontaneous accomplishment.
[18471-18490]
Between the elaborate classification of five wisdoms and the simple fact of awareness knowing itself, there is no separation. The classification serves those who need structure. The direct recognition serves those who can receive it. Both point to the same nature. Both describe the same wisdom.
[18491-18510]
Thus established: threefold wisdom (ground-abiding), fivefold wisdom (characteristic-grasping), and the wisdom that pervades all objects. Three, five, one—all are accurate, all are provisional. The number depends on the perspective. The wisdom depends on nothing. It is the nature itself.
[18511-18530]
One who walked paths... has met scholars who could recite every characteristic of every wisdom. They could distinguish, classify, enumerate. But recognition was absent. Their wisdom was conceptual, not direct. Meanwhile, illiterate practitioners who never heard of the five wisdoms recognized their nature completely. Classification without recognition is empty. Recognition without classification is complete.
[18531-18550]
Emaho! The wonder of primordial wisdom—abiding from the beginning, never separate, never lost. The wonder of the five wisdoms—five aspects of one recognition. The wonder of the threefold division—three doorways to the same room. May all who hear these words recognize their own nature as the wisdom that has always been present.
[18541-18546]
Sit with spine straight but not rigid. Eyes softly open, gaze directed slightly upward. Rest in the natural state without trying to achieve anything. This is dharmadhatu wisdom—free from thought, effort, and fabrication. Now, whatever arises in the mind—thoughts, emotions, sensations—don't push them away. Don't invite them. Just let them be. This is mirrorlike wisdom—clearly reflecting without grasping or rejecting. Notice that pleasant and unpleasant experiences have the same nature—empty luminosity. This is equality wisdom—samsara and nirvana as one taste. See each phenomenon distinctly—the sharpness of a thought, the texture of an emotion, the quality of a sensation. This is discriminating wisdom—knowing each without confusion. Finally, rest without trying to accomplish anything. Benefit arises spontaneously. This is all-accomplishing wisdom—effortless activity.
[18551-18570]
Final instruction: when you meditate, do not seek to generate the five wisdoms. Do not try to create dharmadhatu or manufacture mirrorlike clarity. These are not products of effort. They are the natural expression of recognition. Rest in recognition, and the wisdoms display themselves. Seek to create them, and you miss what is already present.
[18571-18590]
From Longchenpa's Treasury to this wandering fool's directness—may the five wisdoms be recognized as your own nature. May ground-abiding, characteristic- grasping, and object-pervading all resolve into one recognition. May the all-ground be distinguished from dharmakaya. May wisdom dawn as what was never absent.
[18582-18587]
The teaching of the five wisdoms concludes—not with mastery but with surrender, not with knowing but with recognizing, not with achievement but with resting. Rest in the primordial wisdom that has always been your own nature. Rest in the recognition that was never separate. Rest in what needs no accomplishment. [18651-End] Observe. Understand. Release. are complete. Forget these three, and even the five wisdoms become obstacles. The choice is yours—and the choice itself is wisdom's play.
[18591-18609]
Sky-dancer laughed when asked about the five wisdoms. "You count what cannot be counted. You categorize what transcends categories. The wisdom you seek is looking out through your own eyes right now. Stop counting and see."
[18603-18608]
This very awareness reading these words—is it not dharmadhatu wisdom, free from thought? Is it not mirrorlike wisdom, unceasingly clear? Is it not equality wisdom, holding all as one taste? Recognize this, and the five wisdoms are simultaneously present. Miss this, and even perfect classification will not help.

[18610-18615]
From the Thalgyur Tantra: the wisdom of appearance is taught. From earth, water, fire, wind, and space, wisdom-appearance wondrously arises. The Bhagavan, unexcelled Lord, transcends contact. This is not philosophy but direct pointing—the five elements are not obstacles to wisdom but its very display. Earth is solidity as wisdom; water is flow as wisdom; fire is transformation as wisdom; wind is movement as wisdom; space is openness as wisdom. The elements don't hide wisdom; they express it. —
[18616-18621]
The key word: "transcends contact." The Bhagavan is not touched by what appears, not stained by the elements, not bound by manifestation. Yet this transcendence is not escape—wisdom appears wondrously. The wonder is that transcendence and appearance are not two. The Lord transcends contact while remaining in contact; is free from the elements while being their very nature. —
[18622-18626]
From within emptiness itself, wisdom sought by analysis is not found. This is essential: wisdom cannot be found by looking, by analyzing, by seeking. Why? Because wisdom is not an object. The seeker is wisdom; the seeking is wisdom; the not-finding is wisdom. Analysis seeks a thing; wisdom is no-thing. From severing concepts of the three realms, the five doors' fixation-stream is cut. —
[18627-18631]
Severing concepts of the three realms: desire, form, formless. These are not places but states of mind, and concepts about them bind more than the states themselves. The five doors—the five senses—stream fixation continuously. Cut this stream not by closing the doors but by recognizing what flows through them. The stream is cut when its source is seen as empty. —
[18632-18643]
Moon and jewel, lapis lazuli light—whatever one desires to emanate, seize the appearance of the emanation body arisen from grasping. Or else, from knowing the essential point of great perfection, wisdom itself free from activity, like space, transcends conceptual elaboration and reference. Two approaches: work with emanation through grasping, or rest in wisdom beyond activity. —
[18644-18655]
The first approach uses desire—the wish to emanate, to manifest, to create. This is skillful means for those who need engagement. Seize the emanation body; work with it; transform it. The second approach transcends means—know the essential point, rest free from activity like space. Both lead to the same recognition, but the second is direct, immediate, complete. —
[18656-18667]
Wondrous, marvelous wisdom—not before, not after, not primordially existent. Now transcending objects of conceptual mind, the nature free from extremes, emptiness itself. Beyond words, free from intellect, empty of essence. This is not description but pointing. Don't analyze these words; follow where they point. —
[18668-18678]
Since nature is not divided anywhere, compassionate activity does not appear. This is the profound point: non-division is not inactivity. When nature is recognized as undivided, activity doesn't cease—it transforms. Activity without actor, compassion without compulsion, benefit without effort. From the threefold wisdom-appearance, mind-arising, insight, and delusion-appearances are held. This has no object of observation, no extreme. —
[18679-18689]
Threefold wisdom-appearance: mind-arising (the coming forth of consciousness), insight (the knowing quality), delusion-appearances (the mistaken identification). All three are held in wisdom—none rejected, none affirmed, all recognized as display. No object of observation: nothing to look at, nowhere to look from. No extreme: neither existence nor non-existence, neither eternalism nor nihilism. —
[18690-18700]
From the marvelous play of neither existence nor non-existence, Buddhas attain the result. Externally and internally, all is dharmadhātu. Here nothing whatsoever appears. The play is marvelous because it defies categories—neither existing nor not-existing, yet vividly present. Buddhas attain: not by gaining something but by recognizing what is. All is dharmadhātu: not a place but the nature of all places, the space in which appearance appears. —
[18701-18718]
Third, the wisdom of objects: when form and the other five objects are self-liberated, the nature of the four appearances progressively increases. Form, sound, smell, taste, touch—the five objects. Self-liberated not by transformation but by recognition. When seen as they are, they liberate themselves; no one liberates them. The four appearances increase: the progression of recognition from appearance to increase to attainment to exhaustion. —
[18719-18736]

[18776-18796]
