Voice of finality: This completes the commentary on the Thalgyur Tantra's teaching on wisdom appearance. The all-ground has been distinguished from Dharmakaya. The five elements have been recognized as wisdom display. The objects have been seen as self-liberated. Clear awareness has been pointed out. What remains is not more teaching but direct recognition. May all who read this recognize their own wisdom nature. May all be liberated. EOF —
[19167-19302]
The distinction between all-ground and Dharmakaya is subtle but essential. The all-ground is the ground of both samsara and nirvana, the repository of all habits and tendencies. Dharmakaya is the pure nature of that ground, free from all habits and tendencies. They are not two separate things but one reality seen from two perspectives: obscured and unobscured, unrecognized and recognized. The practitioner does not transform the all-ground into Dharmakaya but recognizes that they were never separate. —
[19277-19302]
Free from sound: not the absence of hearing but the transcendence of the sound-silence duality. Genuine: not fabricated, not constructed. Without words: language points but doesn't capture, indicates but doesn't contain. Rest in this understanding: the instruction is to rest, not to think, not to analyze, not to seek. Just rest in what is. —
[19282-19302]
Warmth, measure, signs—the preliminary experiences, the indications of progress, the marks of approaching recognition. But these too must be transcended. The two truths joined: conventional and ultimate not separate categories but simultaneous aspects. Inseparably joined—not first one then the other, not one inside the other, but two ways of describing one reality. —
[19285-19302]
The wisdom of objects: form, sound, smell, taste, touch. When self-liberated, these don't disappear; they become transparent. The four appearances increase progressively: from the initial recognition of appearance, through its increase, to attainment, to exhaustion. Not linear stages but aspects of deepening recognition. Each appearance has its own experience—unique, particular, specific to that moment of recognition. —
[19291-19302]
Wisdom cannot be found by analysis because it is not an object. The analytical mind seeks things; wisdom is no-thing. The more you analyze, the further you go from wisdom. The moment analysis ceases, wisdom is present—not arrived at, not achieved, but recognized as never absent. This is why the text says wisdom is not found within emptiness itself—not because it is absent but because seeking presumes a seeker and sought, and wisdom transcends this duality. —
[19292-19302]
The wisdom of appearance arises from the five elements—not in spite of them, not by transcending them, but as their very nature. This is the key insight: earth, water, fire, wind, and space are not obstacles to be overcome but expressions to be recognized. The solidity of earth is wisdom's stability; the flow of water is wisdom's adaptability; the transformation of fire is wisdom's power; the movement of wind is wisdom's energy; the openness of space is wisdom's vastness. —
[19297-19302]
From earth, water, fire, wind, and space—wisdom appearance wondrously arises. Each element contributes its quality: earth provides stability, water provides flow, fire provides transformation, wind provides movement, space provides openness. Together they create the field in which wisdom appears. Not separate from wisdom; not other than wisdom; the very fabric of wisdom's display. —
[19298-19302]
From within emptiness itself, wisdom sought by analysis is not found. Emptiness is not a container that holds wisdom; emptiness is wisdom's nature. Analysis looks for something; wisdom is no-thing. Analysis presumes a seeker; wisdom dissolves the seeker-sought duality. When analysis ceases, wisdom is obvious—not because it was found but because it was never lost. —

Object-mind practitioners operate within subject-object duality; they require methodical paths with clear stages. Rigpa-mind practitioners recognize non-dual awareness; they can engage direct pointing. Yet both are classifications of approach, not fixed identities. A practitioner may begin as object-mind and mature into rigpa-mind. The distinction serves teaching, not limitation.

First has preliminaries and main introduction: preliminaries are preparing a retreat house half-open with sunlight's rays, crystal mirror stainless—a preliminary. From the Introduction Ornament Tantra: "The retreat place half-open, hole with sun's rays, mirror clear showing, light display seen outward." There, through Vajrasattva heart mirror's symbol introduction showing previous occurrence. I sat in retreat once... once spent three months preparing a retreat cave. The recognition is not in the setup—it's in the seeing." Don't mistake preparation for practice. The crystal, the mirror, the sunlight—these are conditions, not causes. Recognition happens in awareness, not in setup. Prepare properly, then forget preparation and recognize. Mountain hermit near a high plateau lake understood: the crystal is already pure, the mirror already clear. No need to polish what was never stained. The sunlight already enters—just open the hole. The recognition is not manufactured; it is revealed.

That spiral—right-turning, unerring—marks every being who trained in previous lives. The signs are not decoration. They are the architecture of awakening written in flesh.

[10893-10899]
Bindu essence, definition, division, characteristic, and result—this fivefold presentation reveals what cannot be contained in concepts yet must be indicated for those who seek. The essence: not different, dwelling as one, without duality. What does this mean practically? In your direct experience, is there a separation between that which knows and that which is known? When you look for the boundary, you find none. Bindu and expanse, awareness and space—these are not two substances meeting but one nature expressing in two aspects. The definition: bindu not-change, vast expanse, greatly pervading all. Consider this: throughout all the changes of your life—childhood, youth, age, health, sickness, gain, loss—has that which knows these changes itself changed? The bindu is this unchanging essence, the point of pure presence that never transforms. The division into three—body-dwelling channel bindu, nature path bindu, complete result bindu—maps the journey from obscuration to recognition. Body-dwelling: the essences circulating in channels, the white and red bindus gathered at crown and heart, the physical supports for recognition. Nature path: the bindu as it is recognized and activated through practice. Complete result: the bindu fully actualized as the three kayas. A practitioner in retreat once asked her teacher: "What is this bindu you speak of? Is it something I can find in my body?" The teacher replied: "Close your eyes. Rest without thinking. Now, in that rest, is there something that knows the resting? That knowing is bindu. Is there a shape to it? A color? A location?" The practitioner looked and looked. "No," she said finally. "There is only knowing." "Exactly," said the teacher. "Bindu is not a thing. It is the knowing quality itself. But when you seek it as an object, you miss it. When you rest as it, you find you have never been separate from it." She spent the next three months in meditation, not seeking anything, simply resting in that knowing quality. At the end, she said: "I understand now. The bindu was never in my body. My body is in the bindu. All experience arises within this knowing, this thigle, this drop of pure presence." The fivefold presentation follows the traditional Buddhist analytical framework used to fully establish a topic: essence (ngo bo), definition (mtshan nyid), division (dbye ba), characteristic (mtshan ma), and result ('bras bu). This structure ensures comprehensive understanding from the ontological ground to the practical fruit. The essence of bindu is nonduality—it is not separate from the expanse (dbyings) of emptiness, just as a drop of water is not separate from the ocean. Yet it dwells as one—singular, unique to each individual's continuum—without duality between itself and what it knows. This challenges our ordinary assumption of a knowing subject separate from known objects. In direct experience, can you find a boundary between awareness and its content? The closer you look, the more the boundary dissolves. This is not philosophical idealism but phenomenological fact. The definition emphasizes three qualities: unchanging (ma gyur), vast expanse (klong yangs), and all-pervading (kun la khyab). Unlike conditioned phenomena that arise and cease, the bindu is the unchanging ground of knowing. Its vastness means it is not confined to a particular location or time. Its pervasion means all experience occurs within it, like dreams occurring within sleep. The three divisions correspond to the classic Buddhist triad of base (gzhi), path (lam), and result ('bras bu)—the bindu as it exists naturally, as it is activated through practice, and as it is fully realized. In practice, work with the body-dwelling bindus through subtle body practices. Visualize the white bindu (hang) at the crown chakra, radiant like a moon, representing the masculine principle, skillful means, and the capacity for emptiness. Visualize the red bindu (ah) at the heart center, glowing like a sun, representing the feminine principle, wisdom, and the capacity for appearance. As you breathe, imagine these essences becoming more radiant, dissolving obstructions, preparing the physical and energetic basis for recognition. But don't become attached to these visualizations as ultimate reality. They are supports, fingers pointing. The actual bindu is the pure knowing that perceives these visualizations. As practice deepens, the distinction between the visualizer, the visualization, and the bindu itself dissolves. This is the nature path bindu awakening.
[10886-10892]
Of the body-dwelling, two categories: conventional cause bindu (white and red) and ultimate wisdom bindu (five). The white and red—the father's white essence and mother's red essence—converge at the heart. But do not materialize this. These are symbolic of the union of skillful means and wisdom, of emptiness and appearance. The five wisdom bindus correspond to the five buddha families, the five wisdoms, the five pure lights. The Thalgyur teaches: "Body place is this: in crown and heart channel, unfabricated pure reality dwells. Thus it is spoken." The crown is the seat of the white bindu, the father's lineage, the capacity for emptiness. The heart is the seat of the red bindu, the mother's lineage, the capacity for appearance. When these are recognized, the unfabricated pure reality—your own nature—reveals itself. You need not create this; you need only cease obscuring it. The conventional (kun rdzob) and ultimate (don dam) bindus represent the two truths as applied to subtle physiology. The conventional bindus—the white bodhicitta (byang sems dkar po) and red bodhicitta (byang sems dmar po)—are the physical supports that can be worked with through yogic practices like tummo (gtum mo, inner heat). They are conventional because they are relative, conditioned phenomena that can be increased, decreased, moved, and transformed. The ultimate bindus are the five wisdoms (ye shes lnga)—mirror-like, equality, discriminating, all-accomplishing, and dharmadhatu wisdoms—existing primordially beyond increase or decrease. The symbolism of father (white) and mother (red) is pervasive in Vajrayana, representing the nondual union of means and wisdom, method and insight, skillful activity and profound understanding. But this is not merely symbolic; in subtle body practice, the essences do converge at the heart center, and their union gives rise to the experience of bliss-emptiness (bde stong). The five wisdom bindus correspond to the purification of the five skandhas, the five afflictions, and the realization of the five buddha families. The Thalgyur's verse emphasizes that these are not manufactured through practice but discovered—"unfabricated pure reality" (ma bcos dag pa'i chos nyid) dwells naturally in the crown and heart channels. Practice doesn't create this; it reveals what has always been present, obscured only by conceptual mind. To work with this practically: in your daily meditation, begin by settling the mind. Then, gently bring attention to the crown of the head. Without straining, sense the presence there—the white bindu as a feeling of clarity, openness, space. Then bring attention to the heart center. Sense the red bindu as warmth, presence, vitality. Imagine or feel these two meeting in the heart, their union giving rise to a profound sense of well-being that is not dependent on external circumstances. This is the ground of tummo practice and the foundation for dream yoga and clear light practices. But ultimately, recognize that even these subtle experiences are the play of bindu, not bindu itself. The actual bindu is the knowing of these experiences, the awareness in which they arise and dissolve. Rest in that knowing.
[10876-10885]
Path bindu: good, moved by wisdom wind from within channel. The channels are not merely physical nadis; they are the pathways of subtle energy, the infrastructure through which recognition manifests. The wisdom wind—prana activated by recognition—moves the bindu. Good bindu makes four lamps arise as object. The four lamps are the lamp of the abiding ground, the lamp of the empty bindu, the lamp of the far-reaching water, the lamp of the self-originating wisdom. These are not external lights but modalities of recognition, ways that rigpa illuminates itself. Good peak moves various wisdom analysis within channel. As recognition deepens, discriminating awareness operates spontaneously, not through conceptual thought but through direct knowing. Good bindu possessing ornament, depending on four lamps, shows appearance of increasing experience. The ornament is the play of manifestation—the rich display of phenomena as the expression of wisdom. Nature path bindu is sixfold: reality bindu without fabrication, pervading all; Samantabhadra bindu appearing without good or bad; expanse bindu clear without outer or inner; pure expanse bindu arising without deviation; wisdom bindu dwelling without primordial making; great wisdom bindu appearing directly, unobscured. These six are not separate bindus but six ways of recognizing the single essence. In the remote valleys of Dolpo, there lived a yogini who had mastered the practice of the four lamps. She described her experience: "At first, meditation was like sitting in a dark room. I knew the room was there, but I couldn't see. Then, gradually, a soft light appeared—the lamp of the abiding ground (gzhi sgron). It was like the first light of dawn, not bright but unmistakable. As I continued, the bindu itself began to glow—the empty bindu lamp (thigle stong pa'i sgron me)—like a luminous sphere in the center of vision. Then the far-reaching water lamp (rgyang zhags chu'i sgron me) opened, and I could see the nature of thoughts as clearly as objects in a mirror. Finally, the self-originating wisdom lamp (shes rab rang byung gi sgron me) blazed, and there was no distinction between meditation and post-meditation, between practice and ordinary life. All of it was luminosity." She emphasized that these were not visual hallucinations but shifts in the fundamental mode of perception. "It's not that you see different things. You see the same things differently—transparently, as the play of awareness." The path bindu (lam gyi thigle) describes the transformation that occurs as the bindu is activated through practice. The term "good" (dge ba) indicates virtuous or auspicious bindus—those awakened through recognition as opposed to those obscured by ignorance. The wisdom wind (ye shes kyi rlung) is prana (vital energy) infused with awareness. In ordinary beings, prana moves through the side channels (roma and rkyang ma), fueling dualistic perception and afflictive emotions. Through yogic practice, this prana is drawn into the central channel (dbus ma), where it activates the bindu and gives rise to realization. The four lamps (sgron ma bzhi) are experiential modalities described in detail in the Seventeen Tantras. The lamp of the abiding ground is the fundamental luminosity of awareness itself. The lamp of the empty bindu is the bindu as it appears in vision—spherical, luminous, self-arising. The far-reaching water lamp enables the practitioner to "see" the nature of reality at a distance, penetrating obscurations. The self-originating wisdom lamp is the culmination—rigpa knowing itself directly without object or subject. The six nature path bindus elaborate the qualities of the bindu as realized: unfabricated (uncreated by causes and conditions), pervasive (not limited by space or time), without good or bad (beyond moral dualism), without inner or outer (nondual), without deviation (not falling into extremes), and naturally present (not made by effort). The practical application involves working with the subtle body through practices like vase breathing (bum pa can), kumbhaka (holding the breath), and various pranayamas that move the winds and bindus. These are advanced practices that should be learned from a qualified teacher. However, the essence can be approached more simply: in meditation, as recognition stabilizes, you may naturally experience phenomena becoming more vivid, more luminous, more transparent. This is the play of the bindu. Don't grasp at these experiences as signs of attainment, and don't reject them as distractions. Simply recognize them as the natural expression of awareness. The four lamps may manifest in various ways—as visual phenomena in dark retreat, as enhanced clarity in daily perception, as the ability to "see" the energetic dimension of beings and environments. Whatever arises, maintain the view that it is the display of rigpa. This is the path of self-liberation (rang grol)—not purifying phenomena but recognizing their true nature.
[10866-10875]
Complete result bindu: Dharmakāya bindu single, free of elaboration, beyond identification, primordially pure essence, variously appearing as ways of arising, without any establishing cause. This is the fruition—not something newly achieved, but the bindu recognized as having always been complete. It is single because duality has dissolved. Free of elaboration because conceptual constructs have collapsed. Beyond identification because it cannot be fixed as "this" or "that." The bindu characteristic: free of various pain, round without elaboration, showing awareness appearance, great transparent wisdom, gathering five rims into one as kāya place, essence beyond identification because emptiness does not establish as thing. Consider your own experience: when recognition is stable, suffering loses its grip. Not because circumstances change, but because the one who suffered—the grasping self—is seen through. The roundness is completeness, the absence of edges or limits. Great transparent wisdom—transparent because nothing is hidden, nothing blocked. A great master of the Nyingma tradition lay dying. His disciples gathered around, weeping. "Don't weep," he said, his voice still strong. "I am not going anywhere. The bindu that has been my companion throughout this life—through childhood, through study, through practice, through teaching—is not dissolving. It is simply recognizing itself more fully." He paused, then laughed. "Actually, 'it' is not quite right. 'It' implies something separate from what knows it. There is just this—luminous, empty, aware." He closed his eyes and sat in meditation posture. Hours passed. Then, witnesses reported, a rainbow appeared above the house, and his body began to shrink. By the time they checked again, only hair and nails remained—the sign of the rainbow body ('ja' lus). The complete result bindu had fully manifested. He had not achieved something new; he had simply allowed what always was to be fully recognized, fully expressed. The result bindu ('bras bu'i thigle) describes the final state of realization, but Dzogchen is unique in asserting that ground (gzhi), path (lam), and result ('bras bu) are not sequential stages but simultaneous aspects of a single reality. The Dharmakāya (chos sku) is the truth body, the emptiness aspect of buddhahood. Here it is described as single (gcig)—nondual, undivided, the collapse of all subject-object duality. Free of elaboration (spros bral) means free from the eight extremes of conceptual proliferation (existence, non-existence, both, neither, permanence, cessation, coming, going). Beyond identification (ngos 'dzin med) indicates it cannot be grasped as an object or fixed as a reference point. Primordially pure (ka dag) is the quintessential Dzogchen concept—purity not achieved through purification but intrinsic from the beginning. The bindu's characteristic is described through five qualities: freedom from pain (myang 'das), indicating transcendence of suffering; roundness without elaboration (zlum por spros bral), completeness without conceptual constructs; showing awareness appearance (rig pa snang ba ston), manifesting as the display of knowing; great transparent wisdom (shes rab chen po gsal ba), clear omniscience; gathering five rims (nga skor) into one kāya place (sku'i gnas), integrating all elements into a single mandala of body. These describe the bindu not as a philosophical abstraction but as the living experience of full awakening—pain-free because the cause of pain (grasping) has ended, round because complete, transparent because nothing obscures natural knowing. The contemplation of the result bindu is essential for motivation and orientation. Even though Dzogchen asserts the pathless path and the non-attainment of attainment, we must still practice. Why? Because although the result is primordially present, our recognition of it is not. Practice deepens recognition until it becomes uninterrupted, spontaneous, all-pervasive. To contemplate: visualize yourself as the deity, sitting in the dharmakāya posture, the bindu fully awakened at your heart. Radiate light in all directions, purifying the suffering of all beings, dissolving all into light, and rest in the recognition that this is not imagination but the actual nature of reality. The visualization is a support; the recognition is the practice. Do this regularly—not to "become" enlightened but to familiarize yourself with what you already are. This is the Dzogchen approach: not striving to reach a goal but allowing the goal (which is already reached) to manifest fully.
[10851-10865]
The Thalgyur continues its song: "From that, increase of appearance arises, virtue arising directionless, characteristics unstained by any defect, capacity unceasingly appearing as various play, essence self-pure because characteristics are without duality, nature self-liberated because reasoning arises directionless." This is describing the maturation of recognition. Appearance increases—not diminishes, not escapes into void. But the appearance is virtue, benefit, arising without the directional bias of self-interest. From the Blazing Relics: "Who becomes expanse bindu, this fortunate one sees singly." Singly—non-dually, directly, without the mediation of subject and object. "Empty bindu lamp, self-arising without effort—all these are own experience signs." The empty bindu lamp is the self-recognition of rigpa, arising without contrivance, without production. These signs are not external omens but the natural marks of your own experience when recognition is authentic. A contemporary teacher describes the maturation process: "In the beginning, practice feels like work. You're sitting there, trying to meditate, fighting thoughts, struggling with posture, watching the clock. Then something shifts. Thoughts still arise, but they don't disturb you. You're not fighting anymore; you're resting. This is the beginning of the increase of appearance—appearances become more vivid, more detailed, because you're not filtering them through conceptual mind. Then comes a phase where everything seems magical, meaningful, connected. This is the virtue arising. Eventually, even that settles. There's just this—ordinary, obvious, unremarkable. And yet completely different from ordinary confusion. The appearance is the same, but the knower has changed." He laughed. "People ask, 'How will I know when I'm enlightened?' You'll know because you won't care. The question won't arise. Not because you've achieved something, but because you've stopped seeking. The seeking was the only obstacle." The Thalgyur passage describes the qualities of advanced realization. "Increase of appearance" (snang ba che) seems paradoxical—don't advanced practitioners perceive emptiness? Yes, but emptiness is not nothingness. It is the empty nature of appearance, which means appearance becomes more vivid, not less. When conceptual filters dissolve, perception becomes direct, intense, unmediated. "Virtue arising directionless" (dge ba phyogs med 'char) indicates spontaneous benefit that doesn't aim at particular results. Ordinary virtue is directed—"I will help this person" or "I will create this merit." Directionless virtue flows naturally, benefiting all without distinction, like the sun shining without choosing whom to warm. "Characteristics unstained by any defect" (mtshan nyid skyon gyis ma gos) means phenomena are perceived as they are—pure, perfect, without the projection of impurity. The "capacity" (nus pa) is the enlightened activity that manifests unceasingly as various forms of benefit—teaching, healing, inspiring, liberating. The Blazing Relics (sku gdung 'bar ba) is another of the Seventeen Tantras, and its verses describe the signs of realization. "Seeing singly" (gcig tu mthong) is the nondual perception of the awakened one—not seeing two things (subject and object) but the single display of dharmakāya. The "empty bindu lamp" is the self-recognition of rigpa, empty of inherent existence yet luminous in its knowing. These are not external validations but internal certainties—the recognition knows itself to be authentic. In practice, these verses point to the natural progression of recognition. Initially, one must make effort to recognize. Then recognition becomes easier, more stable. Eventually, it is simply the natural state, effortless and continuous. The signs mentioned—vivid appearance, spontaneous virtue, unstained perception—are not goals to achieve but byproducts of stable recognition. Don't chase them. Simply rest in recognition, and they manifest naturally. If you chase them, you create new obscurations. The "expanse bindu" (klong gi thigle) is awareness as space—vast, open, without center or boundary. When one becomes this, perception is transformed. There is no longer a "you" perceiving "things." There is just perceiving, just knowing, just the play of awareness. This is the fruition of Dzogchen practice—not escape from the world but complete intimacy with it, not cessation of appearance but liberation into appearance, not achievement of a special state but recognition of the ordinary as extraordinary.
[10826-10850]
"Word elaborations cut, other mind not entering even for an instant, no occasion, speech-continuum exhausted from saying, thought to speak to others not possible in this person—how could sound words follow?" This describes the state of one who has fully recognized: conceptual proliferation naturally pacified, the constructed self-world of language and reference naturally dissolved. Not through force, not through rejection, but through the exhaustion of ignorance. "Thus in whom this appears, that one decides the single elaboration-free." Decides—certainty beyond doubt, the decisive certainty of direct knowledge. "Thus possessing signs, even in two years from that, knowing awareness measure, dwelling without separation from expanse and awareness own-appearance—that also dissolves elements to self, without doubt this changes." The timeframe is not rigid; it indicates the natural progression. When recognition is stable, when expanse and awareness are never separate, then even the elements—the grossest level of manifestation—dissolve into their true nature. This is the great transference, the rainbow body, the final dissolution of all fixation. "Thus it is spoken." The final verses describe the culmination of the path: the dissolution of the elements ('byung ba rang la zhi). In Tibetan medicine and cosmology, the body is composed of five elements—earth, water, fire, wind, space. In ordinary death, these dissolve sequentially, producing characteristic experiences. In the great transference ('pho ba chen po), the dissolution is conscious and complete. The physical body, composed of the elements, transforms into light, leaving only hair and nails (which don't contain consciousness). This is the rainbow body ('ja' lus), the full manifestation of the complete result bindu. The "two years" mentioned is not a fixed timeline but indicates that once the signs of maturation are stable, the process is irreversible. The "measure of awareness" (rig pa'i tshad) means recognizing rigpa so completely that there is no separation between the expanse (dbyings, emptiness) and awareness (rig pa, knowing). They are seen as inseparable, not two aspects but one reality with two names. For most practitioners, these verses describe an aspiration and a direction rather than an immediate goal. But they also describe what is possible, what has been achieved by masters throughout history. The point is not to fantasize about rainbow bodies but to practice recognition in this very moment. Each moment of recognition is a microcosm of the great transference—thoughts dissolve, emotions dissolve, fixation dissolves, and there is just the luminosity of awareness. String these moments together, deepen them, stabilize them, and the result described here becomes inevitable. It is not something to achieve but something to allow—the natural fruition of the bindu recognizing itself, the expanse and awareness dancing as one, the play of primordial purity spontaneously perfect. Thus it is spoken. Thus it is. Thus it has always been.

Eight inferior grounds. Four for shravakas—those who hear the dharma. Stream-enterer, once-returner, non-returner, arhat. Four for pratyekabuddhas—those who realize themselves. These are the lower paths. Not the highest, but steps on the way. the crystal cave of Yanglesho hermit... once looked down on the "inferior" grounds. "I'm practicing Dzogchen," he boasted. "I don't need those lesser paths." Foolish pride! The stream-enterer has entered the stream—have you? The arhat is free from desire—are you? Don't despise the lower grounds. They are foundations without which the higher cannot stand.
[11736-11824]
Look at the signs after death. Six days in the south—bodhisattva grounds. Ten grounds: joy, stainless, luminous, radiant, difficult, gone afar, immovable, excellent wisdom, dharma cloud. Plus universal light—eleven total. Each ground a stage. Each stage a recognition. But recognition is not staged. Mountain hermit understood: the ten grounds are like ten valleys in a mountain range. You pass through each one, but Gangri Tokar is one. The perfect joy of the first ground, the stainless clarity of the second—they're not achievements to collect. They're descriptions of recognition deepening.
[11736-11824]
Vidyadhara—holders of knowledge. Four grounds: maturation, life power, great seal, spontaneous accomplishment. These are the higher grounds of tantric practitioners. Not ordered by effort, arising naturally from practice. This wandering yogi met a vidyadhara who had mastered the four grounds. "How long did it take?" he asked. The master laughed. "Lifetimes. But the recognition that ripened them? Instant. The maturation takes time. The realization takes no time."
[11736-11824]
The grounds are not reached and finished. Each ground must be perfected through training. Like a student graduating but still must practice. The path is long. The patience must be great. Don't rush to completion. Between the quick attainment of recognition and the long maturation of grounds, we find the vast middle way. Don't rush. Don't stagnate. The ground is recognized instantly. The habituation takes lifetimes. Both are true.
[11736-11824]

Stop counting and recognize! Singing yogi's gentle wisdom: while you walk your daily path, remember—the stream-enterer is practicing. The arhat is practicing. The bodhisattva is practicing. You're all on the same mountain, just different elevations. Final instruction: the eight inferior grounds, the ten bodhisattva grounds, the four vidyadhara grounds—all are skillful means. The recognition is one. The nature is complete. Don't cling to the stages. Rest in the nature. Emaho! The many grounds, the one recognition, the complete nature spontaneously perfect!

02 23 01 01
[12011-12244]
The disturbances of the world fade, and the inner displays become clearer. Yet do not think 'I must have solitude!' The true solitude is the nature (rang bzhin) of mind itself. The bardo is the intermediate state—the state between death and rebirth, between sleep and waking, between one moment and the next. The word "bardo" comes from "bar" meaning between and "do" meaning two—like a rope connecting two posts. The bardo is that connecting rope, the interval, the gap. In Tibetan, there are many bardos: the bardo of this life, the bardo of dying, the bardo of dharmata, the bardo of becoming, the bardo of dream. All are variations of the same principle: the mind in its naked state, unclothed by concepts.

"I must purify my obscurations," he said. "I must accumulate merit." Meanwhile, liberation was immediate. Those with sharp faculties recognize instantly. Those with dull faculties wander in bardo. The difference is not time—it's recognition.

[-20297--20288] The corpse purification—preparing the mandala, the vase, the dharani. The days represent stages. The emanation benefits beings. The recognition is complete. The teaching opens what was never closed. [Final] The corpse purification practice: preparing the mandala, the vase, the dharani cord. Five lights' mansion arises. The practitioner visualizes Samantabhadra, the yabyum, five families' buddhas. Guru lineage invited, stabilized. OM AH HUM SV AHA—hundred thousand recitations. The dharani purifies: "Negativity and obscurations—all become peace." Vajrasattva visualized, light rays, nectar descending, vase fills. The stages of recognition: gathered days of confusion, pristine awareness days, spontaneous accomplishment. From nine to thirteen days—supreme to excellent to middle. Each stage produces emanation benefits: twenty-seven to thirty-nine days. The days are metaphorical—stages of recognition, not calendar time. Liberation possible at any stage. The corpse becomes mandala. Confusion becomes clarity. The purification is complete. Emaho! The corpse mandala! The vase of five lights! The emanation benefits! What is called delusion is wisdom's play. The treasury is complete.

From Pearl Garland, the essence of fruition: liberation itself is primordial. Not something achieved, not something attained—recognition returning to what was never left. This is the final secret, the ultimate pointing: ka-dag is not a state to reach but the nature of whatever appears. Exhaustion of confusion-ground does not mean destruction of something real—it means seeing through what never existed.
02 25 02 01
[16329-16359]
First has three: General presentation of attainment mode. Specifically explained as being result. Removing contradiction with explaining as path-appearance. First: From essence's ground-appearance appearing as three kayas, shown as attained through power of purifying three gates' stains to be purified. From Thal 'gyur: "Furthermore, the result stages: Dharmakaya by mind's activity, Sambhogakaya obtained through speech's form, Nirmanakaya by body." Thus. These are cause-result of what is to be purified. As spontaneously accomplished by nature, knowing that attainment through causes and conditions is impossible—know this! See? The purification isn't a manufacturing process—you're not building a Buddha from parts. It's removing obscurations from what's already perfect. Like cleaning a mirror: the reflection is already there, you just remove the dust!
02 25 03 01
[16360-16408]
First, it is path-appearance—from the spontaneously accomplished womb of great primordial purity, like entering a house of ultimate result, then emerging from there, needing to appear externally from the primordially pure ground. The mode of appearance appears as abiding-essence-body. There are two path-appearances: those making oneself Buddha before the result, and having made oneself Buddha, the path of guiding trainees through manifest body accomplishing benefit. From this, here we hold the no-more-learning path-appearance as the three kayas being path-appearance AND being result—non-contradictory, connected meaning. Don't you see? The path and result aren't separate events in time—they're different aspects of the same recognition. Like a mirror reflecting: the reflection is both the appearing (path) and the complete image (result) simultaneously!

[16770-16971]
Fourth, the extensive explanation of enumerations—from the five: kaya, speech, mind, qualities, enlightened activity. The nature is complete. Kaya: appearing as whatever form beings believe in, each one's portion, marks and signs complete. Speech: sixty branches' melodious sound, well-connected. Mind: knowing how things are and how many, expansive. Qualities: all dharmas of powers and so forth, knowing perfectly complete. Enlightened activity: turning the Dharma wheel of five perfections, nature of outer, inner, secret three. From the Thalgyur: "Nirmanakaya also: kaya, speech, mind, Qualities and enlightened activity, five aspects. What appears as obstacle is actually the path itself, seen through. Kaya marks and signs, Whatever trainees arise, body emanation. What appears as obstacle is actually the path itself, seen through. Speech word-connection good, Brahma's expanse sixty branches. What appears as obstacle is actually the path itself, seen through. The Treasury of the Supreme Vehicle vast oceanic completion. Never closed. Never opened. Simply what is. Mind by wisdom of knowables, Abiding in intention of twofold benefit. Logical analysis: if liberation were gradual, it would be compounded. But recognition is uncompounded. Immediate. Qualities knowing perfectly complete, Enlightened activity outer, inner, secret, All activities perfectly complete, Abide as five perfections. The apparent complexity resolves in simplicity when recognition dawns—before analysis, already complete. Why wait even a moment! The distinction burns in recognition! The maker dissolves NOW!" This is the complete description of enlightened manifestation—not just form, but speech, mind, qualities, and activity. All five are spontaneously present, naturally complete.
02 25 07 01
[16972-17330]
Definitive terminology: "kaya" because body is complete. In the Buddha-ground, though there is neither body nor entity, names alone do not contradict. From the Ratnagotravibhaga (Dkon mchog sgron me): "The dharmakaya is the body of the Victors. By seeing, purifying views, one will know." Just as it is said. Here's the key point: Dharmakaya isn't a physical body, yet it's called "body." Sambhogakaya has no marks, yet it appears with marks. Nirmanakaya has no fixation, yet it appears in various forms. These aren't contradictions—they're the play of emptiness and appearance (stong gzugs)!
